title: World | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News World UN official says Israel expanding Gaza operations would risk 'catastrophic consequences' The UN's assistant secretary general says reports of the possible move are "deeply alarming". 1 hr ago Middle East Despite Trump's peace calls, Russian attacks on Ukraine double since inauguration Missile and drone attacks on Ukraine are now higher than at any other point of the war, according to Ukrainian data. 7 hrs ago World Texas governor seeks court order to fire top Democrat who fled in row over voting map "There must be consequences," says the governor as Democrats insist they will not return to Texas. 3 hrs ago Titan sub firm used 'intimidation tactics' and 'critically flawed' safety practices, Coast Guard report finds The family of two passengers who died in the implosion call for tougher regulation in response to the US Coast Guard's damning report. Rescuers in Norway search for missing US climate journalist Alec Luhn Bad weather in Folgefonna National Park is hampering the search for Luhn, who was last seen on 31 July. 9 hrs ago Europe Despite Trump's peace calls, Russian attacks on Ukraine double since inauguration Missile and drone attacks on Ukraine are now higher than at any other point of the war, according to Ukrainian data. 7 hrs ago World RFK Jr cancels $500m in mRNA vaccine development in the US Since taking office, the vaccine sceptic has made a number of changes to how vaccines are regulated. 4 hrs ago US & Canada Hiroshima marks 80 years since atomic bombing Japan's leader Shigeru Ishiba and officials from across the world attended the annual ceremony in Hiroshima. 5 hrs ago Asia Texas governor seeks court order to fire top Democrat who fled in row over voting map "There must be consequences," says the governor as Democrats insist they will not return to Texas. 3 hrs ago Former Romanian President Ion Iliescu dies aged 95 He was Romania's first freely elected leader after communism fell in 1989, and later faced charges of crimes against humanity. Great Barrier Reef suffers worst coral decline on record Reefs have been battered by cyclones and starfish that eat coral, but heat stress driven by climate change is the main cause of damage. Clintons subpoenaed to testify in congressional Epstein investigation Former top officials from the justice department during the Obama, Trump and Biden administrations were also sent subpoenas. Zelensky thanks Trump for 'productive' talks ahead of ceasefire deadline US envoy Steve Witkoff will visit Moscow on Wednesday, as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine looms. Besieged Sudan city residents face starvation, UN warns El-Fasher, encircled by RSF paramilitary fighters, has not had food deliveries for over a year. Features Propaganda or fair warning? Taiwanese TV show imagines Chinese invasion Zero Day Attack wants to raise awareness of China's threat, but has also been accused of fearmongering. Stay or go? Under Trump, dreams fade for Chinese who trekked to US Migrants living in unease under President Trump have quietly begun to ask themselves: is America worth it? How Trump's secondary tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. Ion Iliescu: Romania's first democratic leader with a divisive legacy His three terms saw the tumultuous birth of modern Romania as it moved from communism to democracy. How a Texas showdown could reshape Congress - and Trump's presidency A dramatic redistricting fight could spread to other states before next year's crucial midterm elections. Watch/Listen 'Hiroshima survivor stories were painful to draw' Hiroshima students have spent weeks visualising the stories of survivors from the atomic bomb and turning them into art. 'I'm upset, angry and disgusted,' Epstein accuser tells BBC Haley Robson says recent speculation Ghislaine Maxwell could be pardoned has left her "extremely angry". Watch: Fireworks ignite as blaze hits Japanese festival launch boats Launch barges at a fireworks festival in Japan's city Yokohama caught fire after pyrotechnics landed on them. Watch: Florida police officer removes alligator from family's pool with bare hands The reptile was retrieved by the officer and buckled into the back of a police car. Latest updates 37 mins ago More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 37 mins ago 1 hr ago UN official says Israel expanding Gaza operations would risk 'catastrophic consequences' The UN's assistant secretary general says reports of the possible move are "deeply alarming". 1 hr ago 3 hrs ago Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. 3 hrs ago 4 hrs ago Clintons subpoenaed to testify in congressional Epstein investigation Former top officials from th

title: Latest news from around the world | The Guardian
body: Africa Hide Prince Harry among those criticised in report on dispute at Sentebale charity Watchdog says all parties, including trustees, patrons and chair Sophie Chandauka, should not have had row in public 8h ago Rwanda agrees to take up to 250 migrants from the US Scores dead as boat carrying more than 150 people capsizes off Yemen Gunmen kidnap more than 50 people in north-west Nigeria Family of Kenyan woman allegedly murdered by UK soldiers criticise defence secretary All Africa stories Americas Hide Ireland calls on Haiti to secure release of group kidnapped from local orphanage An Irish missionary and three-year-old child are among eight people taken by gunmen who stormed the place 9h ago US Coast Guard releases report calling Titan disaster a ‘preventable tragedy’ 11h ago Canada wildfires: 81 million Americans under air quality alerts as blazes rage US steps up efforts to help Bolsonaro avoid jail over alleged coup plot Scientists identify bacterium behind devastating wasting disease in starfish All Americas stories Asia Pacific Hide US research station staff evacuated from Antarctica in high-risk operation Travel to Antarctica during the southern winter is ‘tragedies’ 3h ago Video shows rare protests in China over beating of schoolgirl by three teenagers ‘Don’t erase the soul of Bingin’: Bali locals dismayed as 48 businesses destroyed in local crackdown to be played in Outback Wrangler helicopter crash trial 29m ago All Australia stories Europe Hide UK to bear transport costs of ‘one in, one out’ asylum seeker deal with France Treaty can be ended by either side at a month’s notice and France can refuse returns on certain grounds 8h ago Man who lit cigarette from French war memorial flame faces legal action 12h ago Drone that crossed into Lithuania from Belarus represents ‘alarming sign of spillover of Russia’s aggression’, says Lithuanian minister – as it happened ‘We didn’t vote for ChatGPT’: Swedish PM under fire for using AI in of rubble, dust and graves: how Gaza looks from the sky Israel-Gaza war: Netanyahu deciding on next steps amid reports he could escalate conflict – as it happened Israeli cabinet meeting postponed as tensions rise over Netanyahu’s occupation plan All Middle East and north Africa stories South and Central Asia Hide About 100 people missing as flash flood tears through town in northern India Large-scale search and rescue operation under way after at least four people killed in Himalayan region Trump’s demand that India stop buying Russian oil puts Modi in tight spot Suspected gunmen go on trial in Moscow over concert hall terror attack India to still buy oil from Russia despite Trump threats, say officials Myanmar junta ends state of emergency as it prepares for elections All South and Central Asia stories UK Hide Two ‘misleading’ heat pump adverts banned by UK watchdog ASA says online ads from Aira and EDF Energy omitted key facts about eligibility for government grants 2h ago coastline by beach clean volunteers 8h ago Rachel Reeves needs to put up taxes to cover £40bn deficit, thinktank says 8h ago All UK stories US Hide RFK Jr’s health department to halt $500m in mRNA vaccine research Agency to end 22 federal contracts, questioning safety of technology credited with helping end Covid pandemic 5h ago Trump threatens fleeing Texas Democrats with FBI as Greg Abbott calls for ‘consequences’ – live updates 5h ago California wildfire scorches 83,000 acres and threatens hundreds of structures 5h ago US immigration to hold 1,000 detainees in Indiana after deal with prison system 6h ago Texas senator asks FBI to help

title: BBC Home - Breaking News, World News, US News, Sports, Business, Innovation, Climate, Culture, Travel, Video & Audio
body: Despite Trump's peace calls, Russian attacks on Ukraine double since inauguration Missile and drone attacks on Ukraine are now higher than at any other point of the war, according to Ukrainian data. 7 hrs ago World RFK Jr cancels $500m in mRNA vaccine development in the US Since taking office, the vaccine sceptic has made a number of changes to how vaccines are regulated. 4 hrs ago US & Canada Despite Trump's peace calls, Russian attacks on Ukraine double since inauguration Missile and drone attacks on Ukraine are now higher than at any other point of the war, according to Ukrainian data. 7 hrs ago World RFK Jr cancels $500m in mRNA vaccine development in the US Since taking office, the vaccine sceptic has made a number of changes to how vaccines are regulated. 4 hrs ago US & Canada LIVE UN official says Israel expanding Gaza operations would risk 'catastrophic consequences' Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is pushing for a total reoccupation of the Gaza Strip, according to Israeli media reports. Hiroshima marks 80 years since atomic bombing Japan's leader Shigeru Ishiba and officials from across the world attended the annual ceremony in Hiroshima. 5 hrs ago Asia Oceangate's Titan whistleblower: 'People were sold a lie' A former Oceangate employee says he told US authorities about safety concerns with the sub before it imploded. 1 hr ago Science & Environment Zara ads banned in UK for 'unhealthily thin' models It comes after the advertising watchdog banned M&S and Next ads for showing models who appeared too thin. 8 hrs ago Business How Trump's secondary tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. 7 hrs ago Europe Only from the BBC Propaganda or fair warning? Taiwanese TV show imagines Chinese invasion Zero Day Attack wants to raise awareness of China's threat, but has also been accused of fearmongering. The community embracing a 'man-eating' crocodile It's known for its deadly bite, but the Philippine crocodile – thought to be the rarest in the world – has a lot more to give than it gets credit for. Global News Podcast Former US President Bill Clinton ordered to testify about Jeffrey Epstein Bill and Hillary Clinton are to testify to Congress about Jeffrey Epstein 27 mins Save More news Stay or go? Under Trump, dreams fade for Chinese who trekked to US Migrants living in unease under President Trump have quietly begun to ask themselves: is America worth it? 7 hrs ago World Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. 3 hrs ago Asia Towering tornado spirals over Inner Mongolia A state media report said no casualties were caused when the tornado touched down in the region. 7 hrs ago Asia Violent Channel smuggling gang's French and UK network exposed by undercover BBC investigation Exclusive: Secret filming reveals smugglers' forest hideout and cash deals at UK train station. 15 hrs ago Europe Racer killed in 280mph crash while trying to break land speed record Chris Raschke died at the famous Bonneville Salt Flats, where rocket-shaped cars attempt to set new records. 11 hrs ago US & Canada Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. 3 hrs ago Asia More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 38 mins ago Asia WhatsApp deletes over 6.8m accounts linked to scams, Meta says Many of the accounts were linked to criminal groups operating in South East Asia, the social media giant said. 5 hrs ago Business Towering tornado spirals over Inner Mongolia A state media report said no casualties were caused when the tornado touched down in the region. 7 hrs ago Asia Must watch What is gerrymandering? We use gummy bears to explain Texas Republicans have proposed a controversial redistricting plan. The BBC's Bernd Debusmann explains gerrymandering... in just 60 seconds. 9 hrs ago US & Canada 'Hiroshima survivor stories were painful to draw' Hiroshima students have spent weeks visualising the stories of survivors from the atomic bomb and turning them into art. 9 hrs ago Asia Secret filming at UK rail station of cash payments to gang for illegal Channel crossings Two men met a BBC undercover reporter on the busy concourse at Birmingham's New Street Station. 15 hrs ago Europe Massive clouds of smoke blanket parts of California as Gifford fire grows The cause of the fire, which is threatening more than 800 structures and is only 7% contained, is still under investigation. 12 hrs ago World Terrifying video shows flash flood engulfing riverside village in India Dozens are feared trapped after a cloudburst triggered floods in northern India's Uttarakhand state. 20 hrs ago

title: BBC News - Breaking news, video and the latest top stories from the U.S. and around the world
body: News News LIVE UN official says Israel expanding Gaza operations would risk 'catastrophic consequences' Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is pushing for a total reoccupation of the Gaza Strip, according to Israeli media reports. More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 36 mins ago Asia WhatsApp deletes over 6.8m accounts linked to scams, Meta says Many of the accounts were linked to criminal groups operating in South East Asia, the social media giant said. 5 hrs ago Business RFK Jr cancels $500m in mRNA vaccine development in the US Since taking office, the vaccine sceptic has made a number of changes to how vaccines are regulated. 4 hrs ago US & Canada Oceangate's Titan whistleblower: 'People were sold a lie' A former Oceangate employee says he told US authorities about safety concerns with the sub before it imploded. 1 hr ago Science & Environment More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 36 mins ago Asia Hiroshima falls silent for prayers 80 years on from atomic bombing Japan's leader Shigeru Ishiba and officials from across the world attended the annual ceremony in Hiroshima. 5 hrs ago Asia Despite Trump's peace calls, Russian attacks on Ukraine double since inauguration Missile and drone attacks on Ukraine are now higher than at any other point of the war, according to Ukrainian data. 7 hrs ago World Propaganda or fair warning? Taiwanese TV show imagines Chinese invasion Zero Day Attack wants to raise awareness of China's threat, but has also been accused of fearmongering. 8 hrs ago Asia WhatsApp deletes over 6.8m accounts linked to scams, Meta says Many of the accounts were linked to criminal groups operating in South East Asia, the social media giant said. 5 hrs ago Business Towering tornado spirals over Inner Mongolia Violent Channel smuggling gang's French and UK network exposed by undercover BBC investigation Carol Kirkwood: Why weather forecasters (like me) often appear to get it wrong Zara ads banned for 'unhealthily thin' models No bullying found in Harry charity row, but blame for all sides More to explore Stay or go? Under Trump, dreams fade for Chinese who trekked to US Migrants living in unease under President Trump have quietly begun to ask themselves: is America worth it? 7 hrs ago World 'Hiroshima survivor stories were painful to draw' Hiroshima students have spent weeks visualising the stories of survivors from the atomic bomb and turning them into art. 9 hrs ago Asia Watch: What is gerrymandering? We use gummy bears to explain Texas Republicans have proposed a controversial redistricting plan. The BBC's Bernd Debusmann explains gerrymandering... in just 60 seconds. 9 hrs ago US & Canada Rescuers in Norway search for missing US climate journalist Alec Luhn Bad weather in Folgefonna National Park is hampering the search for Luhn, who was last seen on 31 July. 9 hrs ago Europe How secondary US tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. 7 hrs ago Europe 'Hiroshima survivor stories were painful to draw' Hiroshima students have spent weeks visualising the stories of survivors from the atomic bomb and turning them into art. 9 hrs ago Asia Watch: Secret filming shows Channel gang associates take payment at UK station Two men met a BBC undercover reporter on the busy concourse at Birmingham's New Street Station. 15 hrs ago Europe How a Texas showdown could reshape Congress - and Trump's presidency A dramatic redistricting fight could spread to other states before next year's crucial midterm elections. 11 hrs ago US & Canada Watch: What is gerrymandering? We use gummy bears to explain Texas Republicans have proposed a controversial redistricting plan. body: Business Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. 2 hrs ago Asia How Trump's secondary tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. 7 hrs ago Europe Sign up to World of Business Gain the leading edge with global insights for the boardroom and beyond, in your inbox every Wednesday. body: Culture The film that won an Oscar despite a BBC ban Prof John Cook, from Glasgow Caledonian University, says people are still "wowed" by The War Game. Front Row Sean Hayes, from Will & Grace, on his Tony Award-winning stage show Good Night, Oscar Sean Hayes' play opens in London and how composer Shostakovich survived Stalin's purges. 42 mins Save Entertainment news The Repair Shop's Jay Blades charged with rape Chris Hemsworth on facing fears, ageing and return of Thor Radio personality James Whale dies aged 74 Soulja Boy arrested on suspicion of weapons charges Watch list 10 of the best TV shows to watch this August From the first ever Alien series to the new run of Netflix's Addams Family spin-off and a true-crime drama about Amanda Knox. 12 of the best films to watch in August From The Naked Gun to Freakier Friday – these are the films to watch at the cinema and stream at home this month. From our Culture editors Why Pac-Man remains a beloved icon The yellow eating machine revolutionised video games 45 years ago. What has made Pac-Man and his adventures so addictive? Mississippi Burning: The shocking murders that sparked change in the US In August 1964, three civil rights activists were found dead in the Deep South. The public's response provided the impetus for new civil rights legislation in America. Is £7m for a handbag absurd or justified? As a pop-up handbag auction opens in London, a fashion frenzy is gripping venerable auction houses – and sending prices sky high. Can fashion ever be on a par with a Picasso? Why the Statue of Liberty is at the heart of a culture war Controversy over an Amy Sherald painting of the Statue of Liberty reveals divides over US national symbols, joining debates that have centred on the statue since it was first unveiled. Why Madonna's decades-old Ray of Light is 2025's hottest album From FKA Twigs to Addison Rae, many of today's hottest pop stars are taking inspiration from Madonna's swirling 1998 masterpiece. What is it that has made the album such a touchstone? How Gwyneth Paltrow became a divisive, defiant icon Her larger-than-life persona has led to both admiration and criticism. The author of new book Gwyneth: The Biography, tells the BBC what fascinates her about the star. After defying all expectations, he told the BBC in 1977 how he willed himself to stay alive. How a fatal accident ended Ted Kennedy's presidential hopes In July 1969, Senator Edward Kennedy pleaded guilty to fleeing the scene of an accident where a young aide died. But many questions about the 'Chappaquiddick incident' went unanswered. The scientist who redefined chimps - and human beings Jane Goodall began her groundbreaking field study 65 years ago by living among chimpanzees in Tanzania. In 1986, she told the BBC how similar chimps and humans really are. title: BBC Arts | Theatre, Opera, Art, Classical Music, Dance
body: Arts Why the Statue of Liberty is at the heart of a culture war Controversy over an Amy Sherald painting of the Statue of Liberty reveals divides over US national symbols, joining debates that have centred on the statue since it was first unveiled. Artist explores the toxic mining legacy of Zambia's 'black mountains' A major exhibition about the dangerous lives of the boys and young men who scour slag heaps in search of copper. The last custodian: A Kashmiri artisan's battle to save a musical legacy Ghulam Mohammed Zaz fears for the future of the hand-made santoor as there are no takers for the dying artform. Arts in Motion In a pioneering new collaboration, the BBC – in partnership with Rolex – celebrates excellence in arts and culture. See more Performing Arts Brian Cox returns to the Scottish stage as Edinburgh festivals begin The veteran actor stars in a play about the banking collapse that sent shockwaves around the world. See more Watch The artist who reveals the hidden colours of history How black-and-white photos are being brought back to life. 23 Feb 2022 Art How a robot inspired my ballet dancing Quantum physicist Merritt Moore explains how robot technology helped her new sequences of moves. 23 Feb 2022 Technology The women reviving a vanishing musical legacy This six-piece band has overcome a lot of opposition to be able to play Islamic devotional music. 30 Oct 2021 Asia Unveiling the legend behind a mythical ancient ruler A single piece of jade tells the story of mythical Chinese ruler Sage King Yu 23 Feb 2022 Art The musical mountaineers serenading the wilderness Two mountaineering musicians are combining classical music with the stunning scenery of the Cascade Mountains in Washington State. 23 Feb 2022 Music Around the world Why the 'Virgin Queen' never married Elizabeth I is the only English queen never to have married. The iconic Tudor monarch's last visit to Kenilworth Castle 450 years ago may hold some clues. The mysterious origins of the piñata The piñata is a ubiquitous aspect of Mexican culture. Yet how it got to be that way is somewhat of a mystery. What is history’s most enduring tune? Why did this humble tune, first conjured by medieval farmers, capture so many people’s imaginations and even feature in The Addams Family? Andrea Valentino takes a look. Art history 'Smoke and mirrors': Who was the real Andy Warhol? With his famous wig and shades, Warhol cultivated a mysterious, enigmatic persona. Now a new exhibition with unprecedented access reveals the man behind the elaborate façade. How 'dollar princesses' brought US flair to the UK Five works that reveal Banksy's hidden philosophy Nearly 40 years ago, a naked billboard shocked the art world The colour that means life and death Take me to the opera Meet opera's rare male soprano Samuel Mariño is one of only a few male sopranos around - and the Venezuelan says he aims to bring new audiences to the genre. See more Classical music How music saved a teenager's life in Auschwitz After being sent to the Nazi death camp in 1943, Anita Lasker survived by playing in its women's orchestra. In 1996, she spoke to the BBC about her ordeal. The most misunderstood Oscar winner ever Released 40 years ago this month, Miloš Forman's best picture-winning Amadeus is often accused of historical inaccuracies – but the film's critics could be missing the point. Mysterious musical instrument disappearances From a 17th-Century Italian violin stolen from Japan to Drake's lost Blackberry in Mexico, here are musical lost and found mysteries that rival Sir Paul McCartney's. How opera is aiming for net zero Many opera companies are working towards full sustainability, and Glyndebourne is among those aiming to be a force for good, according to a new documentary. How opera can be 'open to everyone' Is the world of opera becoming more inclusive? A new documentary, featuring conductor Antonio Pappano, explores the mission to open up the art form to everyone. The nation that is the 'land of song' Opera star Bryn Terfel emerged from an extraordinary cultural heritage and a nation renowned for its love of singing. "It's the air that we breathe," he explains in a new documentary. title: BBC Travel | Food & drink, History, Destinations, Road trips
body: Travel Costa Rica's nine-course meal in the sky In Monteverde's misty cloud forest, a restaurant suspended in the canopy is offering one of Costa Rica's most immersive dining experiences. Why your holiday may be getting more expensive A series of new climate-focused tourism fees could be the key to preserving some of the world's most beloved – and vulnerable – destinations. The 25 best places to travel in 2025 From bubblegum-coloured lakes in Australia to a solar-powered safari camp in Botswana, these are BBC journalists' top destinations this year. Cold Escapes There's more to Iceland than Reykjavik This more remote part of Iceland offers visitors a deep dive into its fascinating history and authentic culture. Road-tripping Canada's forgotten coastline A sweeping new highway – nearly 25 years and C$1bn in the making – is reshaping life in Newfoundland and Labrador and opening up Canada's iceberg coast. The nation that wants you to embrace your sleepy side Sweden's long, cold nights might put you off going there in winter, unless, that is, you are in search of that elusive 21st-Century luxury: a good night's sleep. In the news US demands $15,000 deposit for visa applicants from two countries Teacher competes in powerchair race across Europe Airport boss sure new owners will build on success Airport offers summer holidays parking discount Need to know: Five-week mountain road closure Adventures The rise of ultra-sport holidays From swimming island to island in Croatia to running 250km through the Sahara, more travellers are trading relaxation for resilience. The Silk Road oasis hiding in plain sight In recent years, Uzbekistan has embarked on an ambitious nationwide tourism boom transforming much of the country. But its beating heart is in a stunning and largely secluded valley. Powerful storms are uncovering long-buried treasures From the beaches of North Carolina to the reefs of Bermuda, powerful storms are uncovering long-lost wrecks – and you don't need to be a pro diver to discover them. Cycling Europe's borderless bike trail Forty years after a tiny Luxembourg village paved the way for border-free European travel, a series of scenic bike paths whisk travellers through the area's vineyard-studded landscape. The secret royal 'pyramids' of Scotland Hidden deep on the Balmoral Estate, the summer residence of the Royal Family, the bewildering Balmoral cairns are slowly revealing their fascinating backstory to visitors. The British Isles' only electric mountain railway The Snaefell Mountain Railway reveals the Isle of Man's forgotten tourism boom – and serves as a gateway to the seven mythological kingdoms. In Pictures A technicolour visit to Morocco's holiest town Closed for centuries to outsiders, Moulay Idriss is a sacred place bathed in colour and tradition – and it makes a welcome respite from the crowds of Chefchaouen. The SpeciaList Where to get the best pizza in Chicago Local pizza expert Steve Dolinsky wants you to know that Chicago pizza isn't just deep dish. Just in time for Lollapalooza Chicago 2025, here are his favourite pies in the city. Tracee Ellis Ross' top tips for travelling solo The black-ish actor is her own favourite travel companion. Here are her top tips for taking on the world one destination at a time, all on your own. A chef's guide to the best pizza in Naples Expert Daniele Uditi believes that to understand pizza, you need to eat it in the place it was invented. Here are his top pizza picks in Naples. Chiwetel Ejiofor's summer guide to London Everyone is happy when the sun comes out in London – including BAFTA-winning British actor Chiwetel Ejiofor. Here are his top ways to enjoy summer in the capital, from museums to markets. How to explore Glastonbury's Pagan side Rollo Maughfling helped pioneer Glastonbury's modern Druidic revival. Here are his top ways to enjoy the spiritual town beyond its famous festival, from sacred sites to Pagan wares. Jimmy Choo's well-heeled guide to Kuala Lumpur His shoes ignited a worldwide sartorial revolution, but he hangs his hat in KL. Here are his top hometown experiences, from enjoying street food to designing your own bespoke suit. Atsuko Okatsuka's guide to Los Angeles The quirky Drop Challenge comedian finds community in multicultural LA. Here are her top ways to enjoy the city, from catching live comedy to getting hot pot with her grandmother. Where an IndyCar driver hangs out in Indianapolis Former Indianapolis 500 champion Marcus Ericsson hails from Sweden but calls Circle City home. Here are his top local recommendations ahead of the Indy 500. body: Earth Great Barrier Reef suffers worst coral decline on record Reefs have been battered by cyclones and starfish that eat coral, but heat stress driven by climate change is the main cause of damage. Gorillas seek out old female friends even after years apart Carol Kirkwood: Why weather forecasters (like me) often appear to get it wrong Sign up to Future Earth More climate news Funds for the rural army tackling Scotland's wildfires Farmer installs solar panels on part of land Thousands to spend second night without power after Storm Floris Massive clouds of smoke blanket parts of California as Gifford fire grows RSPB nature reserve closed after wildfire Future Planet The community embracing a 'man-eating' crocodile It's known for its deadly bite, but the Philippine crocodile – thought to be the rarest in the world – has a lot more to give than it gets credit for. Sea cucumbers are 'janitors of the sea' - and these women are their guardians Sea cucumbers scour and clean the seafloor, allowing other animals to thrive. In the Philippines, a group of women stands guard to help them multiply. So how does a cheetah catch its target? 8 days ago Natural wonders Alligators and humans coexist in this high-end golf course On the east coast of the US, alligators and humans have learned to co-exist, most dramatically in golf courses. 15 Jul 2025 Natural wonders Greatest Standoff: T.rex vs Triceratops Watch as a T.rex and fully-grown Triceratops face off in a brutal stand-off that shakes the earth. 9 Jul 2025 Natural wonders Watch river dolphins play with local children River dolphins in Mocajuba in Brazil are known to play with people without guarantee of reward. 8 Jul 2025 Natural wonders Watch water monitor lizards look for food in Bangkok These scavenger lizards have found a way to seek food in an urban metropolis like Bangkok. 1 Jul 2025 Natural wonders Hungry cub makes bold move to beat the pack Miss too many opportunities and these young Arctic foxes could become too weak to survive. 24 Jun 2025 Natural wonders Even giant dinosaurs have a soft spot Disturbing the sleep of a Spinosaurus is a dangerous move, unless you're his family. 18 Jun 2025 Natural wonders Baby elephant takes a muddy tumble Watch a funny fall turn serious as mum Cyclone steps in to protect her calf from a clumsy big brother. 17 Jun 2025 Natural wonders Clever baby otter uses rock to open mussel They are one of the few animals to master tool use, and this clever pup needs to learn how in order to be less dependent on its mother. 10 Jun 2025 Natural wonders Watch a T. rex ambush a young triceratops Pioneering special effects recreate the heart-stopping escape of an orphaned baby triceratops from a T. rex. 4 Jun 2025 Natural wonders Watch a bat's unusual encounter with a pitcher plant The carnivorous plant attracts not just insects but mammals too, and for a good reason. 3 Jun 2025 Natural wonders Pelican spider lures prey with an old trick It has mastered its hunting method over millions of years but will it be successful? 27 May 2025 Natural wonders Inside the lab where baby sharks are born Watch how scientists in Japan are rescuing the unborn pups of pregnant sharks killed in fishing nets. 21 May 2025 Natural wonders Watch the improbable comeback of the white tern Down to a single pair, the white tern population has benefited from busy roads and planted trees in Honolulu, Hawaii. 20 May 2025 Natural wonders Dramatic moment monkey family defends baby from python Leaf monkeys are close-knit family groups that work together to protect themselves and newborns. 13 May 2025 Natural wonders Daring langurs cross over busy roadway A new monkey bridge in Malaysia provides hope for wildlife navigating fragmented habitats. 9 May 2025 Natural wonders Inside the Japanese town where deer roam free The long-standing coexistence between people and deer in Nara faces disruption each autumn as male deer compete for mates. 8 May 2025 Natural wonders Why space debris is a looming crisis In the past decade, the dramatic surge in satellite launches has left space cluttered with junk. 2 May 2025 Weather & science Lemur mum has ingenious idea to save newborn from ticks Newly discovered behaviour shows a group of lemur mothers inventing a self-medication method involving ants. 29 Apr 2025 Natural wonders Watch rare Gobi bear's reaction to finding water The critically endangered Gobi bears undertake arduous journeys of up to 100 miles (160km) to find water. 23 Apr 2025 Natural wonders More Earth 1 day ago Countries gather to thrash out deal on 'plastic crisis' The world's nations are hoping to sign the first global plastic treaty to limit plastic pollution

meta_description: As we face the world’s greatest environmental challenges, BBC Earth brings you solutions in psychology, food, climate change, health, social trends, and technology that can make the world a more sustainable place.

title: BBC Video - World class video news and storytelling from around the world.
body: Video Towering tornado spirals over Inner Mongolia A state media report said no casualties were caused when the tornado touched down in the region. 6 hours ago Share Explore More What is gerrymandering? We use gummy bears to explain 8 hrs ago US & Canada 'Hiroshima survivor stories were painful to draw' 8 hrs ago Asia Secret filming at UK rail station of cash payments to gang for illegal Channel crossings 14 hrs ago Europe Massive clouds of smoke blanket parts of California as Gifford fire grows 11 hrs ago World Terrifying video shows flash flood engulfing riverside village in India 19 hrs ago Asia Watch as mischievous bear cub turns house into playground 20 hrs ago Natural wonders Fireworks ignite as blaze hits Japanese festival launch boats 21 hrs ago Asia 'I'm upset, angry and disgusted,' Epstein accuser tells BBC 1 day ago US & Canada Editor's picks The secret behind Colombia's blender craze A colourful journey through fruit markets and forests reveals a nation’s most beloved kitchen ritual. 24 Jul 2025 Culture & Experiences Inside the world of South Korean male beauty pageants What does it take to be crowned as the most beautiful man in the country? 22 Dec 2023 Style What makes the emperor penguin an egg-cellent father In the BBC Select documentary Penguins: Spy in the Huddle, we explore the world of penguin fathers. 2 Jun 2024 World of wonder What's behind Mona Lisa's indescribable smile? Art critics explain why people see Mona Lisa’s smile in different ways. 19 May 2023 Art How an advanced civilisation vanished 2,500 years ago Myth and mystery surround the ancient Tartessos civilisation that vanished 2,500 years ago. 7 Jun 2023 Archaeology Puglia's elders keeping a pasta tradition alive Writer Carmen Roberts tours Puglia's coast, meeting local elders who are trying to preserve a pasta tradition. 4 Nov 2024 The Travel Show ASMR: How whispering took over the internet We meet the creators behind the current ASMR boom. 4 Jan 2023 Work Culture Inside the largest private gothic palace in Venice Discreetly located in a sleepy Venetian square, Palazzo Fortuny surprises whomever ventures in. 26 Apr 2024 Travel Arts in Motion The Paris Opera wants you to 'feel first, understand later' Go behind the scenes of the historic Paris Opera to discover why no prep is required to experience opera. See more Exploring The Americas Earth's spectacular and remote 'capital' of lightning With storms occurring between 140 and 160 nights a year, it's no wonder this remote part of Venezuela is a world-record holder. 6 Aug 2024 World of wonder Who ruled Mesoamerica before the Maya? Long before famous empires such as the Maya, a civilisation called the Olmec were building an impressive legacy. 28 Mar 2022 History 'The most beautiful river in the world' Every year, Colombia's Caño Cristales transforms into a rushing rainbow - in a natural display that happens nowhere else on Earth. 6 Nov 2023 Nature The engineering marvel lost in the Brazilian tropics Paranapiacaba is a Victorian architectural gem hidden in the middle of the Brazilian Atlantic Forest. 10 Jul 2023 History The truth behind the 'walking' statues of Easter Island In a remote patch of the Pacific Ocean lies Rapa Nui, otherwise known as Easter Island, and its colossal Moai. 10 Jul 2023 Archaeology Who discovered the equator – the Spanish or the pre-Incas? A search for who discovered the equator reveals remarkable ancient pre-Inca knowledge. 29 Sep 2022 Science The remote churches on the edge of the world In a remote archipelago of Patagonia, 152 wooden churches hide a secret strength in their structure. 24 Jan 2023 Travel The Bahamas: The last lighthouse of its kind Reece Parkinson heads to the Bahamas, where he meets a community adapting to unpredictable weather patterns. 26 Aug 2024 The Travel Show In case you missed it Explaining how a touchscreen works with a sausage British mathematician Hannah Fry digs into the science of touchscreens. 2 days ago Science Building's hard problem: Can concrete go green? Tech Now visits a Dutch startup producing a more sustainable alternative to concrete. 5 days ago Tech Now Pedro Pascal joins Marvel after lemonade stand ambush The actor explains how his Fantastic Four fate was sealed by a bold kid with citrus and connections. 6 days ago Film & TV Watch a cheetah up close as it chases its prey The fastest animal on land rarely uses its top speed to capture prey. So how does a cheetah catch its target? 8 days ago Natural wonders El Clasico: The beautiful game in a city of resistance The Travel Show visits Barcelona to see how the local club plays a huge role in defining Catalan identity. 28 Jul 2025 The Travel Show High-tech tools cracking the case of Chile's lost children Tech Now visits organisations in Chile using innovative tech to track down missing relatives. 25 Jul 2025 Tech Now The health benefits of drinking matcha tea As a self-confessed coffee addict, Melissa Hogenboom examines the science behind matcha tea's health benefit

title: BBC Live & Breaking World and U.S. News
body:
Live Now LIVE UN official says Israel expanding Gaza operations would risk 'catastrophic consequences' Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is pushing for a total reoccupation of the Gaza Strip, according to Israeli media reports. Follow Live now Recently Live Rangers put three past Plzen to take big step towards Champions League play-offs Russell Martin said he was "really proud" of his Rangers side's response in their three-goal first-leg win against Viktoria Plzen in Champions League qualifying. title: Israel Gaza war | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Israel-Gaza war He is a human skeleton, Gaza hostage's brother tells BBC Ilay David says the Hamas video showing his brother Evyatar emaciated and weak is a "new form of cruelty" that has left his parents shattered. 2 days ago Middle East Hundreds of Israeli ex-officials appeal to Trump to help end Gaza war It comes amid reports that PM Netanyahu is pushing to expand Israel's military operations in Gaza. 2 days ago Middle East Government plans to bring more Gazan children to UK for treatment The government says it is working "at pace" on plans to evacuate seriously ill or injured children from Gaza. 3 days ago Middle East Tens of thousands turn out for Sydney pro-Palestinian march The Sydney Harbour Bridge was closed by the march, after it was authorised to go ahead by the Supreme Court hours earlier. 2 days ago World Hamas refuses to disarm until Palestinian state established Negotiations between Israel and Hamas for a ceasefire and the release of hostages stalled last week. 4 days ago Middle East Hundreds of Israeli ex-officials appeal to Trump to help end Gaza war It comes amid reports that PM Netanyahu is pushing to expand Israel's military operations in Gaza. 2 days ago Middle East World leaders condemn videos of emaciated Israeli hostages in Gaza as Red Cross calls for access Hamas said it would allow Red Cross access if humanitarian aid corridors were opened into Gaza. 2 days ago Middle East Aid group says worker killed by Israeli military in attack on Gaza HQ The Palestine Red Crescent Society accuses Israel of a "direct" strike - Israel says it is reviewing the claim. 2 days ago Middle East Government plans to bring more Gazan children to UK for treatment The government says it is working "at pace" on plans to evacuate seriously ill or injured children from Gaza. 3 days ago Middle East Analysis 'Thank you, but it's too late': Why some Palestinians aren't convinced by Starmer's promise Some say Britain's decision is an important first step – while others worry it won't make a real difference, writes BBC's International Editor Jeremy Bowen. What does recognising a Palestinian state mean? Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has announced that the UK will recognise a Palestinian state in September unless Israel meets certain conditions. Watch: How did Gaza get to the brink of starvation? The BBC's diplomatic correspondent Paul Adams explains how the people of Gaza have reached a point of starvation. The delicate politics behind the UK's move on Palestinian statehood The government's statehood policy marks a hugely significant shift in the UK's diplomatic stance. Bowen: Air dropping aid is an act of desperation that won't end hunger in Gaza Air drops can look good on television, but deliver very little aid and endanger civilian lives. Human stories Two girls shot in Gaza - BBC pieces together what happened and looks at dozens more child shootings Layan and Mira were killed in proximity to IDF soldiers - the Israeli military says intentional harm to civilians is prohibited and their cases will be examined by the authorities. Gazan boy first to be treated in UK for war injuries Majd, 15, was almost killed by an Israeli tank shell last February. He has finally arrived in the UK for reconstructive surgery. 'We need a real solution': Gazans welcome aid plan but fear it will not end crisis Israel says aid convoys will be allowed into Gaza, after weeks of mounting pressure and warnings of starvation. 'I'm so tired': Mother of starving Gazan baby speaks to BBC Hedaya al-Muta'wi's 18-month-old son Mohammed suffers from malnutrition due to famine, weighing just 6kg. He went to get aid and didn't come back - stories of people killed in Gaza As aid agencies warn of "mass starvation", the BBC hears from the relatives of some of those killed in the past week. Latest updates 1 hr ago UN official says Israel expanding Gaza operations would risk 'catastrophic consequences' The UN's assistant secretary general says reports of the possible move are "deeply alarming". 1 hr ago 16 hrs ago Netanyahu to propose full reoccupation of Gaza, Israeli media report The plan will involve a complete takeover of Gaza, but reportedly faces opposition from military chiefs. 16 hrs ago 2 days ago He is a human skeleton, Gaza hostage's brother tells BBC Ilay David says the Hamas video showing his brother Evyatar emaciated and weak is a "new form of cruelty" that has left his parents shattered. 2 days ago 2 days ago Hundreds of Israeli ex-officials appeal to Trump to help end Gaza war It comes amid reports that PM Netanyahu is pushing to expand Israel's military operations in Gaza. 2 days ago 2 days ago Tens of thousands turn out for Sydney pro-Palestinian march The Sydney Harbour Bridge was closed by the march, after it was authorised to go ahead by the Supreme Court hours earlier. 2 days ago 2 days ago Aid group says worker killed by Israeli military in attack on Gaza HQ The Palestine Red Crescent Society accuses Israel of a "direct"

title: Ukraine War | Latest News & Updates| BBC News
body: News News War in Ukraine Kremlin plays down Trump's nuclear rhetoric as US envoy set to visit Moscow The comments come as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine or face sanctions edges closer. 2 days ago World Ukraine drone attack causes fire at Sochi oil depot, Russia says Meanwhile, Ukraine reports Russian air strikes on the southern cities of Kherson and Mykolaiv. 3 days ago Europe They escaped Ukraine's front lines. The sound of drones followed them As technology transforms the war in Ukraine, soldiers are experiencing a new form of trauma: "Droneophobia". 4 days ago Europe Zelensky demands tougher sanctions after Russian strikes kill 31 in Kyiv It comes after the capital saw one of the most deadliest assaults since Russia's 2022 invasion. 5 days ago Europe At least 28 killed in Kyiv as wave of Russian strikes defies Trump ceasefire demand Three children, aged three, six, and 17, were among those killed in the attack, Ukrainian officials say. 5 days ago Europe Ukraine drone attack causes fire at Sochi oil depot, Russia says Meanwhile, Ukraine reports Russian air strikes on the southern cities of Kherson and Mykolaiv. 3 days ago Europe Ukraine officials held in military drone corruption probe The arrests come just two days after Ukraine's anti-corruption agencies had their independence restored. 3 days ago Europe Trump moves nuclear submarines after Russian ex-president's comments US President Donald Trump says two nuclear submarines are being deployed in the "appropriate regions". 4 days ago World They escaped Ukraine's front lines. The sound of drones followed them As technology transforms the war in Ukraine, soldiers are experiencing a new form of trauma: "Droneophobia". 4 days ago Europe Analysis Putin and Trump's relationship has soured - but behind the posturing, a Ukraine deal is still possible Steve Witkoff is visiting Moscow this week - is it a sign that an agreement between Russia and the US to end the fighting in Ukraine could yet be reached? Steve Rosenberg: Russia is staying quiet on Trump's nuclear move The US president said he's ordered two nuclear submarines to move closer to Russia, after a social media spat with Russia's ex-president. Putin not swayed by Trump's Ukraine war ultimatum The Russian president says Moscow's initial tough demands must be met, despite a looming US sanctions deadline. Russian soldiers scammed and robbed of war cash on return from Ukraine A number of cases emerge of servicemen targeted for their salaries and pay-offs by government officials. Backlash grows after Zelensky strips anti-corruption bodies of independence Protests gather pace in Ukrainian cities as some of Kyiv's closest allies sound alarm bells. On the ground School-leavers losing their lives for Russia in Putin's war with Ukraine Russia has promised that no 18-year-olds will be sent to fight in Ukraine, but the BBC finds many have already been killed. Russia's summer push in Ukraine targets three fronts but faces stern resistance Analysis of Russia's advance in northern and eastern Ukraine in maps. 'It's Groundhog Day': Ukraine's sky defenders stuck in relentless battle Under fire of 100 drones a night, there's little talk of a ceasefire in the front-line city of Sumy. The doctor fighting for women's health on Ukraine's front line Dr Baksheiev, a gynaecologist, travels to front-line areas in his kitted out mobile clinic. 'Mariupol is diseased': Residents deny Russian claims occupied city returning to normal Russian shattered Mariupol with a months-long siege in 2022. Now, it says it's rebuilding it. Q&A: Big protests, brief talks and pressure on Zelensky Ukraine saw nationwide demonstrations over controversial anti-corruption reforms. Latest updates 7 hrs ago How Trump's secondary tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. 7 hrs ago 7 hrs ago Despite Trump's peace calls, Russian attacks on Ukraine double since inauguration Missile and drone attacks on Ukraine are now higher than at any other point of the war, according to Ukrainian data. 7 hrs ago 12 hrs ago Zelensky thanks Trump for 'productive' talks ahead of ceasefire deadline US envoy Steve Witkoff will visit Moscow on Wednesday, as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine looms. 12 hrs ago 1 day ago Putin and Trump's relationship has soured - but behind the posturing, a Ukraine deal is still possible Steve Witkoff is visiting Moscow this week - is it a sign that an agreement between Russia and the US to end the fighting in Ukraine could yet be reached? 1 day ago 2 days ago MP drives 1,300 miles to deliver aid to Ukraine Rachel Taylor drove an ambulance full of humanitarian aid on the three-day trip to the Poland-Ukraine border. 2 days ago 2 days ago Kremlin plays down Trump's nuclear rhetoric as US envoy set to visit Moscow The comments come as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine o

title: US & Canada | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News US & Canada Texas governor seeks court order to fire top Democrat who fled in row over voting map "There must be consequences," says the governor as Democrats insist they will not return to Texas. 3 hrs ago How a Texas showdown could reshape Congress - and Trump's presidency A dramatic redistricting fight could spread to other states before next year's crucial midterm elections. 11 hrs ago US & Canada How Trump's secondary tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. 7 hrs ago Europe Massive clouds of smoke blanket parts of California as Gifford fire grows The cause of the fire, which is threatening more than 800 structures and is only 7% contained, is still under investigation. 12 hrs ago World Man accused of killing 4 and abandoning baby arrested in Tennessee The family was found dead and the infant - in a car seat - was left abandoned at a stranger's home about 40 miles away. 8 hrs ago US & Canada How a Texas showdown could reshape Congress - and Trump's presidency A dramatic redistricting fight could spread to other states before next year's crucial midterm elections. 11 hrs ago US & Canada RFK Jr cancels $500m in mRNA vaccine development in the US Since taking office, the vaccine sceptic has made a number of changes to how vaccines are regulated. 4 hrs ago US & Canada Stay or go? Under Trump, dreams fade for Chinese who trekked to US Migrants living in unease under President Trump have quietly begun to ask themselves: is America worth it? 7 hrs ago World How Trump's secondary tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. 7 hrs ago Europe Clintons subpoenaed to testify in congressional Epstein investigation Former top officials from the justice department during the Obama, Trump and Biden administrations were also sent subpoenas. 'Vote him out!' - Republican lawmaker Mike Flood heckled by constituents The Nebraska representative faced backlash over President Trump’s tax and spending bill, which was signed into law in July. Titan implosion that killed all five on board was 'preventable', says report A damning report from the US Coast Guard says Oceangate, that owned and operated the Titan, failed to follow safety protocols. US demands $15,000 deposit for visa applicants from two countries The 12-month pilot programme targeting Malawi and Zamia aims to curb visa overstays, the US says. Zelensky thanks Trump for 'productive' talks ahead of ceasefire deadline US envoy Steve Witkoff will visit Moscow on Wednesday, as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine looms. US Election Unspun Sign up here Cut through the noise with North America correspondent Anthony Zurcher's newsletter - in your inbox every Wednesday. See more Watch/Listen 'Vote him out!' - Republican lawmaker Mike Flood heckled by constituents The Nebraska representative faced backlash over President Trump’s tax and spending bill, which was signed into law in July. 'I'm upset, angry and disgusted,' Epstein accuser tells BBC Haley Robson says recent speculation Ghislaine Maxwell could be pardoned has left her "extremely angry". Watch: Florida police officer removes alligator from family's pool with bare hands The reptile was retrieved by the officer and buckled into the back of a police car. Watch: Fire breaks out on commuter train connecting New Jersey and NYC Several people were treated for smoke inhalation. Features Why Donald Trump is talking about actress Sydney Sweeney The actress stars in a controversial American Eagle advert that has become a political flashpoint in the US. Putin and Trump's relationship has soured - but behind the posturing, a Ukraine deal is still possible Steve Witkoff is visiting Moscow this week - is it a sign that an agreement between Russia and the US to end the fighting in Ukraine could yet be reached? After a blown deadline, what next for US-Canada trade? There are pressures on both sides to give businesses a reprieve, but the tone remains markedly downbeat. Five things now pricier in Canada due to tariffs From cars to ketchup, the US tariffs and Canadian counter measures are pinching pocket books. Trump's global tariffs 'victory' may well come at a high price The US president considers it a win - but if this all triggers a foundational realignment, the results may not break in his favour Latest updates 4 hrs ago Clintons subpoenaed to testify in congressional Epstein investigation Former top officials from the justice department during the Obama, Trump and Biden administrations were also sent subpoenas. 4 hrs ago 4 hrs ago RFK Jr cancels $500m in mRNA vaccine development in the US Since taking office, the vaccine sceptic has made a number of changes to how vaccines are regulated. 4 hrs ago 8 hrs ago Man accused of killing 4 and abandoning baby arrested in Tennessee The family was found dead and the in

title: UK | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News UK UK Politics England N. Ireland Scotland Wales Reeves must raise tax to cover £41bn gap, says think tank The chancellor will miss her self-imposed rules without action, the National Institute for Economic Affairs says. 22 mins ago Business No bullying found in Harry charity row, but blame for all sides The Charity Commission criticises “all parties” at Sentebale for allowing a “damaging” dispute to play out publicly. 6 hrs ago Africa MasterChef returns after Wallace and Torode sacked Gregg Wallace and John Torode were both sacked following a report into conduct on the BBC show. 28 mins ago Culture Call to vet YouTube ads like regular TV to stop scams Liberal Democrats say regulations need to catch up with "the reality of how people are watching content". 5 hrs ago Family in tribute to Oasis fan who died at Wembley Lee Claydon, a 45-year-old from Bournemouth, died after falling from a height at Saturday's concert. 11 hrs ago Culture No bullying found in Harry charity row, but blame for all sides The Charity Commission criticises “all parties” at Sentebale for allowing a “damaging” dispute to play out publicly. 6 hrs ago Africa Zara ads banned for 'unhealthily thin' models It comes after the advertising watchdog banned M&S and Next ads for showing models who appeared too thin. 8 hrs ago Business Struggling families 'need grants' for school uniforms Grants are offered as standard in Scotland, Wales and NI - but only by a quarter of councils in England. 8 hrs ago Business MasterChef returns after Wallace and Torode sacked Gregg Wallace and John Torode were both sacked following a report into conduct on the BBC show. 28 mins ago Culture 'Facial recognition tech mistook me for wanted man' Shaun Thompson is challenging the Met Police's use of live facial recognition technology. Police deny Reform council leader's claims of rape case 'cover-up' The Chief Constable says he has asked the Home Office to confirm the men's immigration status. Hiking couple drowned in flash flood on holiday Alexander Barrett and Sarah Thompson died during a hiking trip on holiday. Boss of water regulator Ofwat to resign David Black's resignation comes after the government said the water regulator will be abolished to create a new watchdog. Couple detained in Iran allowed first call home Joe Bennett says he finally spoke to his mother Lindsay Foreman after several months. Watch/Listen Watch: The latest weather forecast as Storm Floris hits An amber warning came into place at 10:00 BST across large parts of Scotland, with wind gusts expected to reach up to 90mph. Why did 1,000 people watch a man fold a sheet in Edinburgh? David Sillito finds out why Kiwi comedian Dan Boerman performed his laundry-inspired routine on Calton Hill in Edinburgh. Agyemang: 'Winning Euros was so surreal that I cried' England striker Michelle Agyemang says the Lionesses "all believed, from day one" that they could win the tournament. Watch: Zoo unveils 'truly special' red panda cubs Their arrival is described as a "significant step" in conserving the endangered species. Watch: The day the Lionesses brought it home and visited No 10 Sarina Wiegman's triumphant team arrived back in the UK, after becoming the first English team to win a major football tournament on foreign soil. Features & analysis The real reason weather forecasters (like me) often appear to get it wrong The accuracy of forecasting has improved enormously - and AI promises further advances. But there are certain challenges in finding ways to share that mass of data with viewers The Papers:  '£50bn black hole' and parental help from a princess Wednesday's papers lead on the next budget, with Chancellor Rachel Reeves under pressure to stick to her spending promises. Violent Channel smuggling gang's French and UK network exposed by undercover BBC investigation Exclusive: Secret filming reveals smugglers' forest hideout and cash deals at UK train station. Are we getting another UK heatwave or did Storm Floris end summer early? After a spell of wetter and windier weather there are signs of possible drier and warmer days to come.  BBC Weather's Matt Taylor explains. What are the rules around police giving out a suspect's nationality? Home Secretary Yvette Cooper says guidance on what police reveal about suspects "needs to change". More from the UK 'Facial recognition tech mistook me for wanted man' Shaun Thompson is challenging the Met Police's use of live facial recognition technology. Thousands to spend second night without power after Storm Floris SSEN said it was continuing to restore supplies but that some people would be without power until Thursday. I'm feeling the pressure, Morgan says after year as FM Wales' first minister is gearing her party up for the next Senedd election. Police breached duty of care to teen killed in 2018 An investigation finds officers failed to recognise the risk of leaving Shannon McQuillan and her boyfriend alone beside a road. Latest updates 9 hrs ago More

title: Politics | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News UK UK Politics England N. Ireland Scotland Wales Taxes must rise to meet Reeves' rules, says think tank The chancellor will miss her self-imposed rules without action, the National Institute for Economic Affairs says. 7 hrs ago Business Call to vet YouTube ads like regular TV to stop scams Liberal Democrats say regulations need to catch up with "the reality of how people are watching content". 4 hrs ago I'm feeling the pressure, Morgan says after year as FM Wales' first minister is gearing her party up for the next Senedd election. 30 mins ago Wales Corbyn attacks Rayner for selling off allotments The ex-Labour leader - and keen gardener - accuses ministers of threatening a British tradition. 17 hrs ago Politics Rwanda says it has agreed to take up to 250 migrants from the US A condition of the agreement is that Rwanda will "approve each individual proposed for resettlement". 10 hrs ago World Call to vet YouTube ads like regular TV to stop scams Liberal Democrats say regulations need to catch up with "the reality of how people are watching content". 4 hrs ago Police respond to council leader's 'rape cover-up' claim The Chief Constable says he has asked the Home Office to confirm the men's immigration status. 12 hrs ago Coventry & Warwickshire What are the rules around police giving out a suspect's nationality? Home Secretary Yvette Cooper says guidance on what police reveal about suspects "needs to change". 18 hrs ago UK I'm feeling the pressure, Morgan says after year as FM Wales' first minister is gearing her party up for the next Senedd election. 30 mins ago Wales Cooper won't put a number on migrant returns to France The "one-in, one-out" deal, which starts tomorrow, will see some of those arriving in the UK returned to France. 'Tighter gun restrictions make me feel hopeful' A woman whose twin sister and nieces were shot dead welcomes firearm licensing rules which become law. Honours system gets new role to make awards more inclusive A new "diversity and outreach" committee will try to reach parts of society currently missing out on honours. Holyrood childcare provision 'doesn't make sense' - Forbes The Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch MSP announced on Monday that she would not seek re-election next year. MPs write to Yorkshire Water over £1.3m payments The MPs pose questions about £1.3m in payments to Yorkshire Water's chief executive. Features and analysis Jeremy Corbyn's new party needs a name and it's trickier than you might think The ex-Labour leader wants supporters to come up with a name for his new party. After 100 years, is Plaid Cymru on verge of leading Wales? James Williams looks back at Plaid's history as the party celebrates 100 years since it was founded. Hackers, secret cables and security fears: The explosive fight over China's new embassy in the UK It will be the biggest embassy in Europe, if approved. But its opponents fear it brings with it certain risks and dangers What does recognising a Palestinian state mean? Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has announced that the UK will recognise a Palestinian state in September unless Israel meets certain conditions. The delicate politics behind the UK's move on Palestinian statehood The government's statehood policy marks a hugely significant shift in the UK's diplomatic stance. From our Political Editor Chris Mason Chris Mason: Trump visit provides Starmer with invaluable access The PM's time with the president helped burnish a relationship as solid as it is improbable. Chris Mason: Why Labour had little choice but to suspend Abbott again Labour appearing consistent is core to Abbott's second suspension, writes the BBC's Chris Mason. Starmer stamps authority with MP suspensions, but risks appearing vindictive Senior officials say the sackings came after repeated organising against the government. Starmer and Macron plead for patience in an impatient world The UK and France have agreed a "one in, one out" deal for migrants crossing the Channel. Migrant deal will be seen as failure if numbers don't fall The "one-in-one-out" deal with France to be announced later will have to deter people from getting in small boats. BBC InDepth 'Thank you, but it's too late': Why some Palestinians aren't convinced by Starmer's promise Some say Britain's decision is an important first step – while others worry it won't make a real difference, writes BBC's International Editor Jeremy Bowen. Who is in charge? The prime minister's authority is in question again It's been a week of dismissals, disagreements and backbench bust-ups, writes Laura Kuenssberg. Labour might be down, but it's not necessarily out - voters reflect on a year in power What’s gone wrong for Labour? 2024 voters delve into it, writes Laura Kuenssberg. Starmer's stormy first year: Why his political honeymoon was so short-lived As the PM marks a year in office next week - which he will spend grappling with crises - British politics finds itself at an inflection point Crisis - which crisis? title: England | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News UK UK Politics England N. Ireland Scotland Wales 'Facial recognition tech mistook me for wanted man' Shaun Thompson is challenging the Met Police's use of live facial recognition technology. 47 mins ago Police deny Reform council leader's claims of rape case 'cover-up' The Chief Constable says he has asked the Home Office to confirm the men's immigration status. 11 hrs ago Coventry & Warwickshire Family 'nightmare' as search for swimmer continues Matt McDavid, from Leeds, disappeared while swimming off the coast at Flamborough on 30 July. 30 mins ago West Yorkshire Discarded food blamed after 22-inch rat found An increase in vermin in Normanby is blamed on housing developments and food waste. 16 mins ago Tees Hope that campaign to protect tropical tree bears fruit Marline Anderson, who recently died, brought the tree as a sapling from Grenada to the UK in the 1980s. 47 mins ago London Police deny Reform council leader's claims of rape case 'cover-up' The Chief Constable says he has asked the Home Office to confirm the men's immigration status. 11 hrs ago Coventry & Warwickshire Gardener arrested over 'dagger' trowel on his belt Samuel Rowe, 35, says he wants his police caution for carrying a knife overturned. 39 mins ago Manchester Taster finds 33 plates of peas a day appealing Professional taster Michelle Lawrie samples 32 plates of peas at work then has them for her tea. 37 mins ago Hull & East Yorkshire Family 'nightmare' as search for swimmer continues Matt McDavid, from Leeds, disappeared while swimming off the coast at Flamborough on 30 July. 30 mins ago West Yorkshire 'I had 50 rejections before finding a job' Slough has the most out of work benefits claims compared with other boroughs in Berkshire. Call for help with school uniform costs in England Grants are offered as standard in Scotland, Wales and NI - but only by a quarter of councils in England. Farm diversifies with new burial ground A family in Leicestershire has transformed its working farm into a burial ground. Boardmasters drug warning as thousands set to attend Zero tolerance drugs warning from police and organisers as Boardmasters prepares to welcome guests. Rare cloud formation spotted during storm Keen weather watcher Adrian Webster said it was "something I had never seen before". Stories to make you smile Owner amazed by plant after 50 years with family Hilary Chappin says her beloved agave, raised from a pot in the 1970s, is to bloom for the first time. Litter-picking 'obsessed' dog helps clean up coast Black Labrador Logie has an "obsession" for retrieving rubbish from his local area. Tiktok helps young farmer open up on mental health The farmer has started an online initiative to help others in the industry to share their struggles. Features & Analysis 'There's just something magical about the balloon fiesta' More than 2,000 people bring the Bristol International Balloon Fiesta to life every year. Cyclist challenging 'stage four cancer perceptions' Bex Hind says she "refused to sit down and give up" after being diagnosed with a rare cancer. Why people are ripping flowers from waterways Himalayan balsam was a popular garden plant to Victorians, but its spread threatens native species. 'We've got to keep horse fair tradition alive' North Lincolnshire Council says the current site in Brigg has been reserved to build housing. Tensions 'getting worse' year after violent disorder A year after violence erupted across a city, an expert says tensions are escalating again. Watch/Listen The latest weather forecast as Storm Floris hits An amber warning came into place at 10:00 BST across large parts of Scotland, with wind gusts expected to reach up to 90mph. 'Bringing black metal back to the North East' Evil Dungeon Crawler aim to continue the legacy of pioneering fellow Newcastle band Venom. 'Extreme overseas day-tripping is quite addictive' A woman who flies abroad and then returns home on the same day says the journeys can be "pure fun". Sport Man Utd make £74m bid for RB Leipzig striker Sesko Manchester United make a bid for RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko with the overall package potentially rising to 85m euros (£73.8m). 'Winning the Ashes would be Stokes' greatest miracle' Winning the Ashes for England in Australia this winter would be Ben Stokes' greatest miracle, says chief cricket reporter Stephan Shemilt. Dias & O'Reilly close to signing new Man City deals Manchester City reach agreements in principle over new contracts with defender Ruben Dias and midfielder Nico O'Reilly. 'Excellent prospect' Ngumoha stars for Liverpool - but who is he? Liverpool's second youngest ever player Rio Ngumoha shines again in pre-season to get fans wondering if he could be part of the first team this year. Latest updates 20 mins ago Widower fulfils wife's wish of setting up wig bank David Dinsdale says he wants to bring "happiness and relief" to people going through chemotherapy. 20 mins ago 30 mins ago Loss of independent voice "a worry for

title: Northern Ireland | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News N. Ireland N. Ireland Politics Police breached duty of care to teen killed in 2018 An investigation finds officers failed to recognise the risk of leaving Shannon McQuillan and her boyfriend alone beside a road. 7 hrs ago Northern Ireland The play that aims to keep memory of Troubles child alive Julie Livingstone was 14 when she was fatally shot with a plastic bullet in west Belfast in 1981. 29 mins ago Northern Ireland Lyons says library drag queen event 'should not have taken place' Communities minister says a drag queen storytelling event in Belfast was "not appropriate for children". 13 hrs ago Northern Ireland Can video games help stroke survivors regain some movement? The new study will ask stroke survivors to wear a simple headset, which reads brain activity. 16 hrs ago Northern Ireland Nesbitt defends extra money for gender identity services The move faced criticism from the Democratic Unionist Party, Traditional Unionist Voice and some Ulster Unionists. 21 hrs ago Northern Ireland The play that aims to keep memory of Troubles child alive Julie Livingstone was 14 when she was fatally shot with a plastic bullet in west Belfast in 1981. 29 mins ago Northern Ireland Burke family confront NI education official over transgender guidance Members of the family attempted to speak to Mervyn Storey over claims that the Education Authority was "promoting gender ideology". 17 hrs ago Northern Ireland Family of Irish missionary kidnapped in Haiti 'devastated' Gena Heraty, from County Mayo, was taken with eight other people from an orphanage which she runs. 8 hrs ago Europe Lyons says library drag queen event 'should not have taken place' Communities minister says a drag queen storytelling event in Belfast was "not appropriate for children". 13 hrs ago Northern Ireland NI's Burrows cleared of assaulting match official Cliftonville captain Kelsie Burrows is cleared of assaulting a match official following an incident in a game against Glentoran. Irwin joins Yamaha after split from Ducati Northern Irish rider Glenn Irwin joins OMG Yamaha after parting ways with PBM Ducati by "mutual consent" as a result of a disagreement over his return to racing. A5 decision to be appealed, says minister The 58-mile £1.7bn project was given the green light by Stormont ministers in October last year. Sperrins wind farm gets go-ahead after appeal The application to build six turbines at Magheramore near Dungiven was rejected by the council in 2023. New victims commissioner appointed for Northern Ireland Joe McVey, who was awarded an OBE for services to the voluntary sector, will start in October. Features & Analysis Fears over future of outdoor activity centre Sports enthusiasts say they are missing the facility, which is closed while a review takes place. 'I'm doing 5 shows a day' - NI acts take on the Fringe Some artists from Northern Ireland have said the cost of performing at the Fringe is an obstacle. Asbestos illegally dumped 281 times in five years Asbestos was used in building materials until it was discovered that inhalation of fibres could cause cancers. 'West End of the north coast' closes doors for final time Ulster University, which owns the theatre, said the building had come to the end of its life. Foyle & West Highland dancers join Maiden City Festival The Maiden City Festival features many cultural events, including the Apprentice Boys' demonstration. Residents return to homes after security alert ends Police carried out a controlled explosion after a suspicious object was found in Magherafelt, County Londonderry. House fire treated as arson No one was injured in the fire in the Donald's Way area of Limavady, County Londonderry, on Sunday. Huge crowds turn out for outdoor fitness event Organisers of Ebrington Hyrox say it will be one of the biggest outdoor events of its kind on the island of Ireland. Listen: North West Today A round-up of local news, sport and weather across the north west of Northern Ireland. Republic of Ireland Irish missionary and child, 3, among nine kidnapped from Haiti orphanage Gena Heraty and a three-year-old child were taken in the middle of the night in a "planned act", officials say. Swimmer dies after getting into difficulty in County Donegal The woman was airlifted to hospital in Sligo, but was later pronounced dead. Woman who won civil rape case against Conor McGregor to sue him McGregor lost a civil jury appeal on Thursday against the finding that he sexually assaulted Nikita Hand. Dublin mains water may be affected by repair works Some people may experience supply interruptions including low pressure, discolouration and outages. Mother of Irish soldier calls trial where man sentenced to death a 'sham' A man was sentenced to death in Lebanon on Monday over the killing of an Irish soldier on a UN peacekeeping mission. More BBC News NI on iPlayer & Sounds Good Morning Ulster Wake up to Good Morning Ulster and get all the news and analysis from home and abroad. The Nolan Show B

title: Northern Ireland Politics | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body:
News News N. Ireland N. Ireland Politics Nesbitt defends extra money for gender identity services The move faced criticism from the Democratic Unionist Party, Traditional Unionist Voice and some Ulster Unionists. 23 hrs ago Northern Ireland New victims commissioner appointed for Northern Ireland Joe McVey, who was awarded an OBE for services to the voluntary sector, will start in October. 2 days ago Sinn Féin MP 'never felt like a second-class citizen' Pat Cullen recalls confronting a soldier during a checkpoint search in County Tyrone in the 1980s. 7 days ago Northern Ireland Politics Why has the UUP turned to another man in uniform? Jon Burrows joins Ulster Unionist assembly members which include former soldiers and a retired submarine commander. 7 days ago Northern Ireland Politics Ambulance Service will not participate in Pride NIAS will not march in an official organisational capacity and its staff cannot wear NIAS uniforms. 25 Jul 2025 Northern Ireland Politics New victims commissioner appointed for Northern Ireland Joe McVey, who was awarded an OBE for services to the voluntary sector, will start in October. 2 days ago Stormont's performance is 'sub-optimal', says new MLA Jon Burrows is replacing Colin Crawford, who stepped down after less than a year as North Antrim MLA. 2 days ago Northern Ireland Politics Government denies reallocating £1m of peace funding The UK government denies reallocating funding from a cross-border peace project to a new scheme. 6 days ago Northern Ireland Politics Sinn Féin MP 'never felt like a second-class citizen' Pat Cullen recalls confronting a soldier during a checkpoint search in County Tyrone in the 1980s. 7 days ago Northern Ireland Politics Former senior PSNI officer to become UUP MLA He is replacing North Antrim MLA Colin Crawford, who is stepping down after less than a year in the role. Investigation into replacement of top civil servant Mark Browne held the role of permanent secretary for a number of years, including a period when the executive had collapsed. Head of NI Civil Service warned over Belfast Pride involvement Some Stormont parties have questioned NI Civil Service participation over impartiality concerns. Deepfakes to become criminal offence in NI 'sooner rather than later' There is currently no legislation in Northern Ireland to protect adults from the practice. Stormont voting to be extended to 16 and 17-year-olds The change is unlikely to come into place in time for the 2027 elections.
