title: Scotland | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Scotland Scotland Politics Thousands to spend second night without power after Storm Floris SSEN said it was continuing to restore supplies but that some people would be without power until Thursday. 8 hrs ago Scotland Scotland should have 'nightlife minister' like Australia - report The Night Time Industries Association believes Scotland is "behind the curve" in supporting clubs, restaurants and live music venues. 25 mins ago Scotland Death of boy, 10, who fell down manhole was avoidable, sheriff finds Shéa Ryan died in 2020 when he fell down a manhole on a building site in Glasgow. 13 hrs ago Glasgow & West Scotland Rangers put three past Plzen to take big step towards Champions League play-offs Russell Martin said he was "really proud" of his Rangers side's response in their three-goal first-leg win against Viktoria Plzen in Champions League qualifying. Pass rates up for Scottish pupils in latest exam results Certificates are being delivered by first-class post, though many students will also receive a text or email. 15 hrs ago Scotland Politics Scotland should have 'nightlife minister' like Australia - report The Night Time Industries Association believes Scotland is "behind the curve" in supporting clubs, restaurants and live music venues. 25 mins ago Scotland Scotland's papers: SNP pressure over attainment gap 'failure' A review of the front page stories from the daily newspapers in Scotland. 9 mins ago Scotland Funds for the rural army tackling Scotland's wildfires The Cairngorms National Park Authority allocates £270,000 to address the impacts of climate change 26 mins ago Scotland Death of boy, 10, who fell down manhole was avoidable, sheriff finds Shéa Ryan died in 2020 when he fell down a manhole on a building site in Glasgow. 13 hrs ago Glasgow & West Scotland Man who killed his mother with crossbow to remain in hospital Daniel Parker fired a crossbow at his mother, sister and neighbour at his home in Edinburgh. Holyrood childcare provision 'doesn't make sense' - Forbes The Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch MSP announced on Monday that she would not seek re-election next year. Adoption support charity shreds 'irreplaceable' files to save space Birthlink has been fined £18,000 after shredding the files to free up space in its filing cabinets four years ago. Rapist carried out 'horrific' attack in victim's home A judge said aggravating features of the crime included the attempt to degrade the victim and the fact that significant harm was caused to her. Body found in search for missing Kilmarnock woman Michelle Wade's family have been informed of the discovery. Features and analysis SQA results day 2025: What happens after results come out? Around 147,000 students across Scotland will receive their exams results on 5 August. Do we need a minister for disco? Sub Club supremo on the decline of the night out. In pictures: 21st Belladrum Tartan Heart Festival The weekend included performances by Supergrass, Natasha Beddingfield, Peter Capaldi and CMAT. Who is Kate Forbes, Scotland's deputy first minister? The deputy first minister has announced that she will stand down as Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch MSP next year. Your pictures of Scotland A selection of photographs submitted to BBC Scotland News from around the country this week. News from around Scotland Man who killed his mother with crossbow to remain in hospital Daniel Parker fired a crossbow at his mother, sister and neighbour at his home in Edinburgh. Thousands to spend second night without power after Storm Floris SSEN said it was continuing to restore supplies but that some people would be without power until Thursday. Funds for the rural army tackling Scotland's wildfires The Cairngorms National Park Authority allocates £270,000 to address the impacts of climate change Nicola Sturgeon to appear at Wigtown Book Festival Organisers say this year's festival boasts its "largest and most varied programme ever". Pass rates up for Scottish pupils in latest exam results Certificates are being delivered by first-class post, though many students will also receive a text or email. Sport Rangers & Hibs will postpone games if in European play-offs Rangers and Hibernian will both exercise their right to postpone their Scottish Premiership matches on the weekend of 23/24 August if they progress to the play-off stage of European qualifying. Hibs sign Scotland's Hanley on two-year deal Hibernian are in "advanced talks" to sign Scotland defender Grant Hanley, head coach David Gray reveals. Simpson-Pusey ready to 'show talents' at Celtic Jahmai Simpson-Pusey is ready to show his "talent" and his "levels" after joining Celtic on a season-long loan from Manchester City. 'Total chaos' - Clement reflects on 'frustrating' Rangers stint Speaking to Sacked in the Morning, former Rangers manager Philippe Clement says his time at Ibrox was hamstrung by "total chaos" at boardroom level. title: Scotland Politics | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body:
News News Scotland Scotland Politics Holyrood childcare provision 'doesn't make sense' - Forbes The Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch MSP announced on Monday that she would not seek re-election next year. 15 hrs ago Scotland Politics Nicola Sturgeon to appear at Wigtown Book Festival Organisers say this year's festival boasts its "largest and most varied programme ever". 19 hrs ago South Scotland Trial delays for most serious crimes set to grow While the overall workload on the court system is falling, the High Court is dealing with a growing number of cases. 5 days ago Scotland One of world's largest offshore wind farms approved Up to 307 turbines will be built in the project despite concerns about the impact on seabirds. 6 days ago Scotland Call to simplify Scottish disability benefits system A report commissioned by ministers said the Adult Disability Payment is "more compassionate" than the rest of the UK. 6 days ago Scotland Politics Nicola Sturgeon to appear at Wigtown Book Festival Organisers say this year's festival boasts its "largest and most varied programme ever". 19 hrs ago South Scotland Deputy First Minister Kate Forbes to stand down as MSP The Highlands MSP said she did not want to "miss any more of the precious early years of family life". 2 days ago Scotland Politics Pro-Palestinian protests disrupt FM's Fringe event The first minister said he believed Gaza was subject to "a genocide" after being heckled at the event. 4 days ago Scotland Politics Trial delays for most serious crimes set to grow While the overall workload on the court system is falling, the High Court is dealing with a growing number of cases. 5 days ago Scotland Trump parting shot at 'terrible first minister' Sturgeon The US president made an unprompted remark while addressing  journalists on Air Force One. Four arrests after 7,000 police deployed for Trump visit The deployment included 6,144 Police Scotland officers and another 1,197 from other UK forces Health experts issue new warning over synthetic drugs Data from Public Health Scotland suggests a 15% increase in drug related deaths in the second quarter of the year. Trump flies back to the US after whirlwind trip to Scotland The US president has agreed a major trade deal in between playing golf in his mother's homeland. Scottish Green leadership nominations revealed Dominic Ashmole, Ross Greer, Gillian Mackay and Lorna Slater will seek the two co-leader roles. Features and analysis Who is Kate Forbes, Scotland's deputy first minister? The deputy first minister has announced that she will stand down as Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch MSP next year. Trump visit teases glimpse of independent Scotland As the world's eyes turn to Scotland, John Swinney points to a new strategy for independence. Are the Scottish Greens descending into civil war? Patrick Harvie, who is standing down as co-leader, faces a fight for his seat at the next Holyrood election. What does the new Industrial Strategy mean for Scotland? Scotland could be in the sweet spot for elements of the strategy across all the sectors targeted for support. How could politics shape the Scotland of 2050? A conference in Edinburgh invited leaders to think beyond the short-termism of the five-year electoral cycle.

body: News News Wales Wales Politics I'm feeling the pressure, Morgan says after year as FM Wales' first minister is gearing her party up for the next Senedd election. 23 mins ago Wales Ospreys' St Helen's stadium plans approved The Ospreys will relocate to the historic St Helen's ground for the 2025–26 season. 11 hrs ago Wales Man's remains found near his care home after 28 years David Gear went missing from a care home nearly 28 years ago, an inquest is told. 16 hrs ago Wales Homes evacuated after unexploded bomb found About 50 homes have been evacuated after an unexploded bomb is discovered in a garden. 14 hrs ago Wales More than 500 fake Labubu dolls seized at show Powys council says the counterfeit Labubu dolls pose serious safety risks for children. 14 hrs ago Wales Ospreys' St Helen's stadium plans approved The Ospreys will relocate to the historic St Helen's ground for the 2025–26 season. 11 hrs ago Wales Man jailed after brandishing gun in McDonald's Jacob Jenkins is sentenced to four years and one month, with an extended period of three years. 13 hrs ago Wales Planned 50-storey skyscraper would be tallest in Wales The tower would host 500 apartments, meeting rooms, an atrium, a bike hub and cafe. 12 hrs ago Wales Man's remains found near his care home after 28 years David Gear went missing from a care home nearly 28 years ago, an inquest is told. 16 hrs ago Wales I'm a bodybuilder but bowel cancer in my 30s nearly killed me Mat Dean says younger people should have access to bowel cancer screening. New power station to capture own carbon emissions Welsh Secretary Jo Stevens says it is a "significant moment" for the growing clean energy industry. Actor hopes festival can recharge Welsh language in area Actor Mark Lewis Jones hopes festival can "recharge" area's Welsh language and culture. Giant Schnauzer rescued after swimming 200m out to sea A windsurfer helped to get the dog to safety after his owner feared she had lost him. 'Irreplaceable' festival founder dies days after wedding Stu Housley, 49, died of a rare and aggressive cancer on 28 July, days after his final festival. Features & analysis After 100 years, is Plaid Cymru on verge of leading Wales? James Williams looks back at Plaid's history as the party celebrates 100 years since it was founded. Wrexham welcomes thousands to National Eisteddfod Wrexham is rolling out the red carpet to welcome visitors to the National Eisteddfod. The Welshman wrapped in myth who met Hitler and exposed Stalin Welsh journalist Gareth Jones interviewed the major leaders of the world in his short life. Criminals cash in on TikTok Labubu trend with dangerous fakes Labubu doll fans say real ones are increasingly hard to get because of scalpers scooping them all up. The unassuming terraced house decorated like a grand estate Artist Royston Jones has transformed his three-bedroom terrace house into a neo-classical wonder. Sport Wrexham add Wales forward Moore to strikeforce Wales international Kieffer Moore has signed a three-year deal with Wrexham having left Championship rivals Sheffield United. Ospreys' St Helen's stadium plans approved The Ospreys will relocate to the historic St Helen's ground for the 2025–26 season. Prop duo eye Wales recalls after joining Dragons Props Dillon Lewis and Wyn Jones are looking to impress at Dragons to put themselves back in the mix for Wales. 'Don't give up' the Swans message as Sheehan gets big chance Alan Sheehan explains why he is determined to progress with Swansea City as he prepares for his first full season as a head coach. Wilde embarks on new Cymru Premier adventure as Colwyn Bay boss But on Sunday, another chapter in Mike Wilde's long association with the Cymru Premier will begin – that of manager. Stories from Cymru Fyw Rhaid i Lafur 'godi uwchlaw' anghytuno mewnol - Eluned Morgan Mewn cyfweliad i nodi blwyddyn fel prif weinidog, mynnodd Eluned Morgan nad oedd rhwyg o fewn ei phlaid yn dilyn ffrae am ddewis ymgeisydd. Eisteddfod yn 'sbardun' i'r iaith yn Wrecsam a'r cylch Mae'r brifwyl wedi creu egni o'r newydd i ddysgu'r iaith ymhlith pobl yr ardal, meddai rhai. Hwyrnos i dargedu 'pobl sy'n mynd i Greenman, Glastonbury, Primavera' Bydd newidiadau i'r trefniadau adloniant ym Maes B eleni, gyda maes gwersylla i bobl dros 20 oed am y tro cyntaf. Jean Rhoades: Teithio dros 6,000 o filltiroedd i'w heisteddfod olaf? Mae Jean sy'n 94 oed wedi gwneud y siwrne o'i chartref yn Albuquerque i Eisteddfod Wrecsam ar ei phen ei hun ar gyfer ei heisteddfod olaf. title: Wales Politics | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body:
News News Wales Wales Politics I'm feeling the pressure, Morgan says after year as FM Wales' first minister is gearing her party up for the next Senedd election. 23 mins ago Wales After 100 years, is Plaid Cymru on verge of leading Wales? James Williams looks back at Plaid's history as the party celebrates 100 years since it was founded. 1 day ago Wales FM 'big fan' of Labour member at centre of selection row Eluned Morgan backs a high-profile Welsh Labour member who failed to win Senedd election selection. 2 days ago Wales Cardiff bus drivers set to strike for three weeks Cardiff Bus staff - including bus drivers - vote to strike for three weeks over the summer. 2 days ago Wales Unemployment fears for resident doctors over training A union claims more training places are needed as resident doctors struggle to find suitable positions. 6 days ago Wales After 100 years, is Plaid Cymru on verge of leading Wales? James Williams looks back at Plaid's history as the party celebrates 100 years since it was founded. 1 day ago Wales New power station to capture own carbon emissions Welsh Secretary Jo Stevens says it is a "significant moment" for the growing clean energy industry. 14 hrs ago Wales Families pushed out of work due to childcare costs Many parents are choosing not to work to be able to care for their children, a report finds. 18 hrs ago Wales FM 'big fan' of Labour member at centre of selection row Eluned Morgan backs a high-profile Welsh Labour member who failed to win Senedd election selection. 2 days ago Wales Calls for Welsh government to withdraw from housing plan Councillors in Wrexham have called on the Welsh government to withdraw from a controversial housing plan. NHS in England told to keep Welsh patients waiting One woman says the Welsh NHS "can't be bothered" to send letters to patients to explain. Welsh concern over conditions for recognising Palestine It comes after the Prime Minister said recognition is conditional on Israel's actions. Calls to reinvest money from minimum alcohol pricing to help addicts The Welsh government is considering the benefits of raising the unit price for alcohol. Failed festival site bought by taxpayers worth £500k less A farm bought by Welsh government for a festival project which collapsed has lost £500,000 in value.

title: Africa | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Africa Rwanda says it has agreed to take up to 250 migrants from the US A condition of the agreement is that Rwanda will "approve each individual proposed for resettlement". 11 hrs ago World Besieged Sudan city residents face starvation, UN warns El-Fasher, encircled by RSF paramilitary fighters, has not had food deliveries for over a year. 17 hrs ago Africa Nigeria's champion women basketballers promised $100,000 each D'Tigress won their seventh Afrobasket title over the weekend and a spot at the World Cup. 21 hrs ago Africa Ghanaian footballer Thomas Partey granted bail on rape charges The former Arsenal midfielder has been given conditional bail 21 hrs ago UK Sierra Leone WWII hero commemorated in UK town John Henry Smythe is being remembered as a heroic WWII resident after being given a blue plaque. 2 days ago Oxfordshire Besieged Sudan city residents face starvation, UN warns El-Fasher, encircled by RSF paramilitary fighters, has not had food deliveries for over a year. 17 hrs ago Africa Rwandan gorillas seek out old female friends even after years apart A study in Rwanda reveals the significance of a social connection between female mountain gorillas. 7 hrs ago Science & Environment 'Abducted' Ugandan student jailed over anti-Museveni TikTok video The opposition allege the undergraduate, who pleaded for forgiveness in court, was tortured. 14 hrs ago Africa Nigeria's champion women basketballers promised $100,000 each D'Tigress won their seventh Afrobasket title over the weekend and a spot at the World Cup. 21 hrs ago Africa Features and analysis BBC reveals horrific exploitation of children in Kenya sex trade An undercover BBC investigation reveals the women who involve children as young as 13 in sex work. 'I felt an unspoken pressure to smile' - Kenyan women in the workplace Is the pressure to be likeable holding women back at work? Ballet and bioluminescence: Africa's top shots A selection of the week's best photos from across the African continent and beyond. Destination: Africa - is it legal for US to deport foreign criminals to the continent? Two African nations have taken criminals from other countries deported from the US. 'How will we survive?' Lesotho factory that made Trump golf shirts hit hard by US tariffs The uncertainty around the paused tariffs has led to massive layoffs in Lesotho's textile industry. How Trump wants the US to cash in on mineral-rich DR Congo's peace deal The US president is spearheading an ambitious but controversial deal to end a long-running conflict. The would-be Congolese saint murdered 'mafia-style' for refusing bribes Congolese customs official Floribert Bwana Chui Bin Kositi has been beatified for standing up to corruption. Artist explores the toxic mining legacy of Zambia's 'black mountains' A major exhibition about the dangerous lives of the boys and young men who scour slag heaps in search of copper. Sport 'I love to dance' – social media boosts Masaka during injury-hit season After missing out on Wafcon 2024, Tanzania forward Aisha Masaka says social media has helped her stay in touch with home and lifted her spirits. 'Trailblazing' Ugandan player joins women's rugby team 'Trailblazing' Peace Lekuru, who has signed for York Valkyrie, is 'hopefully the first of many'. Barcelona agree shirt sponsorship deal with war-torn DR Congo Despite criticism, the Congolese government says the deal with raise the profile of the country. Hansie Cronje, match-fixing and plane crash that left a complex legacy Hansie Cronje's story, re-examined in Sport's Strangest Crimes on BBC Sounds, is a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma. Le Court makes history in Tour de France Femmes Kim le Court becomes the first African to win a stage at the Tour de France Femmes as she claims stage five on Wednesday. Watch/Listen The women powering up African arm wrestling Nigerian star Burna Boy surprises Lioness coach at victory parade England manager Sarina Wiegman is surprised by her favourite artist Burna Boy during celebrations for the Lionesses' Euro 2025 win. BBC goes inside rebel-held city in DR Congo The BBC revisits the city of Goma six months after it was seized by M23 rebels. The Wafcon star who is also a doctor Morocco midfielder Salma Bouguerche says medicine "chose her" as a career, having qualified as a doctor last year. 'I am the queen of the cage' Nigerian police officer Juliet Ukah will make history when the Professional Fighters League holds its first event in Africa. Programmes and podcasts Live: World Service for Africa Focus on Africa Podcast Three essential stories to round off your working day. Explaining the news from Africa. This is Africa Latest updates 6 hrs ago No bullying found in Harry charity row, but blame for all sides The Charity Commission criticises “all parties” at Sentebale for allowing a “damaging” dispute to play out publicly. 6 hrs ago 14 hrs ago 'Abducted' Ugandan student jailed over anti-Museveni TikTok video The opposition allege the

title: Asia | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Asia China India Hiroshima marks 80 years since atomic bombing Japan's leader Shigeru Ishiba and officials from across the world attended the annual ceremony in Hiroshima. 5 hrs ago Asia More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 37 mins ago Asia BTS deny involvement in Michael Jackson tribute album The K-pop band say reports that they are working on a tribute to the so-called "King of Pop" are false. 18 hrs ago Newsbeat Protests in China over viral school bullying case One protester in Sichuan province said “things got bloody” after police used batons and electric prods. 21 hrs ago Asia China reports 7,000 cases of chikungunya virus The uptick in cases have prompted measures that are being compared to those taken during the pandemic. 24 hrs ago Asia More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 37 mins ago Asia Great Barrier Reef suffers worst coral decline on record Reefs have been battered by cyclones and starfish that eat coral, but heat stress driven by climate change is the main cause of damage. 5 hrs ago Australia Stay or go? Under Trump, dreams fade for Chinese who trekked to US Migrants living in unease under President Trump have quietly begun to ask themselves: is America worth it? 7 hrs ago World BTS deny involvement in Michael Jackson tribute album The K-pop band say reports that they are working on a tribute to the so-called "King of Pop" are false. 18 hrs ago Newsbeat Dozens feared trapped as cloudburst triggers flash floods in India Rescue teams have reached Dharali village in Uttarkashi, which is believed to have borne the brunt of the floods. F1 tycoon pleads guilty to abetting the obstruction of justice Ong had given expensive gifts to a former minister, including an all-expenses paid trip to Qatar. Chinese university students told to spy on classmates, report says Lecturers are also being harassed, the report finds, as ministers say threats will not be tolerated. The witchcraft murders that shook an Indian village Family members are in shock after their loved ones were murdered and allegedly burned alive by a mob. Prominent Indian ex-MP gets life sentence for rape Prajwal Revanna was found guilty of sexually assaulting a former employee. Features Disfigured, shamed and forgotten: BBC visits the Korean survivors of the Hiroshima bomb When the atom bomb was dropped 80 years ago, 140,000 Koreans were in Japan's Hiroshima city, many as forced labour. Hackers, secret cables and security fears: The explosive fight over China's new embassy in the UK It will be the biggest embassy in Europe, if approved. But its opponents fear it brings with it certain risks and dangers The big fat 'fake' Indian wedding - Gen Z's latest party trend Wedding-themed parties - minus the marriage - have become popular among young Indians chasing new experiences. The mystery of Winston Churchill's dead platypus was unsolved - until now The platypus -  a top secret gift from Australia - was found dead in his enclosure as war raged in the seas around him. Indian singer loved - and mocked - for his nasal twang makes a roaring comeback There was a time when Himesh Reshammiya's distinctly nasal songs blared from every Indian street. Now he's back. Latest updates 37 mins ago More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 37 mins ago 3 hrs ago Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. 3 hrs ago 5 hrs ago Hiroshima marks 80 years since atomic bombing Japan's leader Shigeru Ishiba and officials from across the world attended the annual ceremony in Hiroshima. 5 hrs ago 7 hrs ago Towering tornado spirals over Inner Mongolia A state media report said no casualties were caused when the tornado touched down in the region. 7 hrs ago 8 hrs ago Propaganda or fair warning? Taiwanese TV show imagines Chinese invasion Zero Day Attack wants to raise awareness of China's threat, but has also been accused of fearmongering. 8 hrs ago 9 hrs ago 'Hiroshima survivor stories were painful to draw' Hiroshima students have spent weeks visualising the stories of survivors from the atomic bomb and turning them into art. 9 hrs ago 14 hrs ago Bangladesh announces election as country marks year since ex-PM fled Interim leader Muhammad Yunus confirmed the date as the country marked a year since former PM Sheikh Hasina fled. 14 hrs ago 19 hrs ago Dozens feared trapped as cloudburst triggers flash floods in India Rescue teams have reached Dharali village in Uttarkashi, which is believed to have borne the brunt of the floods. 19 hrs ago 20 hrs ago Terrifying video shows flash flood engulfing riverside village in India

title: China | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body:
News News Asia China India Stay or go? Under Trump, dreams fade for Chinese who trekked to US Migrants living in unease under President Trump have quietly begun to ask themselves: is America worth it? 6 hrs ago World Protests in China over viral school bullying case One protester in Sichuan province said “things got bloody” after police used batons and electric prods. 20 hrs ago Asia BBC visits Beijing region hit by deadly flood The BBC's Stephen McDonell is in Miyun, one of the areas hardest-hit by the severe weather. 8 days ago Asia Beijing floods kill 30 as China sees summer of extreme weather President Xi Jinping called for "all-out" rescue efforts and preparation for "worst-case" scenarios. 8 days ago Asia Watch: Nursing home residents rescued from China floods At least 30 people have been killed in floods that have inundated large parts of northeastern China. 29 Jul 2025 Asia Protests in China over viral school bullying case One protester in Sichuan province said “things got bloody” after police used batons and electric prods. 20 hrs ago Asia China reports 7,000 cases of chikungunya virus The uptick in cases have prompted measures that are being compared to those taken during the pandemic. 22 hrs ago Asia More than 30 killed in nursing home hit by Beijing floods Local officials admit "loopholes in emergency planning" and say the incident is a painful lesson that serves as "a wake-up call". 6 days ago Asia BBC visits Beijing region hit by deadly flood The BBC's Stephen McDonell is in Miyun, one of the areas hardest-hit by the severe weather. 8 days ago Asia Features Hackers, secret cables and security fears: The explosive fight over China's new embassy in the UK It will be the biggest embassy in Europe, if approved. But its opponents fear it brings with it certain risks and dangers Chinese university students told to spy on classmates, report says Lecturers are also being harassed, the report finds, as ministers say threats will not be tolerated. Tech manufacturing has powered Asia - now it's a casualty of Trump's tariffs Trump's tariffs in his first term took aim at China - but this time they are going beyond. How a vote targeting 'pro-China' lawmakers has split Taiwan The spectre of Chinese influence in parliament has sparked a movement and fractured Taiwan’s society. Sirens and evacuations as Taipei rehearses to counter China invasion threat Taiwan's capital is holding one of its largest ever civil defence exercises. title: India | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Asia China India More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 30 mins ago Asia Terrifying video shows flash flood engulfing riverside village in India Dozens are feared trapped after a cloudburst triggered floods in northern India's Uttarakhand state. 20 hrs ago Asia Influential tribal leader Shibu Soren dies at 81 Soren was one of the most influential leaders of the tribal-dominated eastern state of Jharkhand. 2 days ago Asia Army officer under investigation for alleged assault on airline staff SpieJet has alleged its staff members suffered a spinal fracture and grevious injuries due to the assault. 2 days ago Asia The big fat 'fake' Indian wedding - Gen Z's latest party trend Wedding-themed parties - minus the marriage - have become popular among young Indians chasing new experiences. 2 days ago Asia Terrifying video shows flash flood engulfing riverside village in India Dozens are feared trapped after a cloudburst triggered floods in northern India's Uttarakhand state. 20 hrs ago Asia Bangladesh announces election as country marks year since ex-PM fled Sheikh Hasina fled to India last year after weeks of student-led protests, ending her 15-year authoritarian rule. 14 hrs ago Asia Which franchise league is most entertaining? BBC Sport crunches the numbers to see which franchise cricket league is providing the best entertainment for fans. 21 hrs ago The Hundred India calls Trump's tariff threat over Russian oil 'unjustified' The US president threatened to "substantially" raise tariffs against India over its purchase of oil from Russia. 1 day ago World Influential tribal leader Shibu Soren dies at 81 Soren was one of the most influential leaders of the tribal-dominated eastern state of Jharkhand. 2 days ago Asia Features Indian singer loved - and mocked - for his nasal twang makes a roaring comeback There was a time when Himesh Reshammiya's distinctly nasal songs blared from every Indian street. Now he's back. England-India Test series best since 2005 Ashes - Agnew The drawn series between England and India has been every bit as "compelling and competitive" as any Ashes series, says Jonathan Agnew. The witchcraft murders that shook an Indian village Family members are in shock after their loved ones were murdered and allegedly burned alive by a mob. Should teen sex be a crime?  Indian woman lawyer mounts challenge India's age of consent is being challenged in court, renewing conversations around the criminalisation of teen sex. Trump's tariffs could deal a blow to India's growth and exports The effect on India's GDP is unclear as Trump announced an unspecified penalty in addition to 25% tariffs. Watch Bobby Friction on one of India's biggest hip-hop stars Punjabi rapper Sidhu Moose Wala was shot dead through the windscreen of his car by hired gunmen in 2022. Abhishek Bachchan: Cricket, India and Me Award-winning Bollywood actor and film producer Abhishek Bachchan on his love of cricket and his involvement in the new European T20 Premier League. Tesla: Milestone as first showroom opens in India The opening of Tesla's first showroom in India is a milestone but not a breakthrough for the country's EV sector. Air India report may lead to answers, but not closure for families As experts analyse the findings of the report, it provides little comfort to the families who lost their loved ones. 'I don't believe it yet': India plane crash victim's brother BBC journalists heard the heart-wrenching stories of families desperate for news of their loved ones. Latest updates 30 mins ago More than 100 missing after flash floods in India Many rescue teams have been unable to reach the area because of damaged roads and bad weather. 30 mins ago 19 hrs ago Dozens feared trapped as cloudburst triggers flash floods in India Rescue teams have reached Dharali village in Uttarkashi, which is believed to have borne the brunt of the floods. 19 hrs ago 20 hrs ago Terrifying video shows flash flood engulfing riverside village in India Dozens are feared trapped after a cloudburst triggered floods in northern India's Uttarakhand state. 20 hrs ago 1 day ago BBC pundits pick their favourite moments from England v India BBC Sport and Test Match Special pundits pick some of their favourite moments from the England v India Test series. 1 day ago 1 day ago India calls Trump's tariff threat over Russian oil 'unjustified' The US president threatened to "substantially" raise tariffs against India over its purchase of oil from Russia. 1 day ago 2 days ago Most dropped catches? Why don't stadiums have roofs? Your questions answered Isa Guha, former England cricketer Ebony Rainford-Brent, former India wicket-keeper Deep Dasgupta and TMS statistician Andy Zaltzman answer your questions. 2 days ago 2 days ago 'England and India provide most intense, dramatic and emotional finale' The fifth Test finale between England and India at The Oval was

title: Australia | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Australia Great Barrier Reef suffers worst coral decline on record Reefs have been battered by cyclones and starfish that eat coral, but heat stress driven by climate change is the main cause of damage. 5 hrs ago Australia Convicted rapist fighting to remain in parliament in Australia The New South Wales parliament wants to expel Gareth Ward after he was last month found guilty of rape. 1 day ago Australia The mystery of Winston Churchill's dead platypus was unsolved - until now The platypus -  a top secret gift from Australia - was found dead in his enclosure as war raged in the seas around him. 3 days ago Australia Finger painting by artist with nerve injury wins Australian art award "Without a brush, painting was almost painless," said Filipina-Australian artist Loribelle Spirovski. 6 days ago Australia Australian childcare worker charged with creating abuse videos Australia is facing a reckoning over safety within its childcare sector, after a series of abuse cases. 6 days ago Australia Convicted rapist fighting to remain in parliament in Australia The New South Wales parliament wants to expel Gareth Ward after he was last month found guilty of rape. 1 day ago Australia Aboriginal group launches legal bid to stop Brisbane Olympic stadium The group says Victoria Park is culturally and historically significant to Indigenous people. 24 hrs ago Australia Tens of thousands turn out for Sydney pro-Palestinian march The Sydney Harbour Bridge was closed by the march, after it was authorised to go ahead by the Supreme Court hours earlier. 2 days ago World The mystery of Winston Churchill's dead platypus was unsolved - until now The platypus -  a top secret gift from Australia - was found dead in his enclosure as war raged in the seas around him. 3 days ago Australia Features & Analysis YouTube to be included in Australia's teen social media ban The Australian government says the world-first ban is aimed at protecting youth from online harm. Why Australians celebrate Christmas twice a year The Australian tradition was born in the 1980s after a group of Irishmen became homesick for a winter Christmas. Can you un-bleach coral? BBC visits remote reef to find out The BBC's Katy Watson went to Australia's Ningaloo reef, the site of a mass bleaching event, to find out if the damage can be undone. An Indigenous Australian community is fighting to protect sacred springs from a coal mine One Aboriginal family has been fighting for nearly a decade to protect the Doongmabulla Springs. The 'underwater bushfire' cooking Australia's reefs Divers at one of Australia's world-famous reefs said their experience was "like swimming on a corpse". Watch/Listen Watch: 'UFO' spotted in Australian skies identified as Chinese rocket Astrophysicists said that the unusual lights spotted over Brisbane were tied to a satellite launch from China. Watch: Huge stick insect discovered in Australia A new "supersized" species of stick insect that is roughly as heavy as a golf ball has been discovered in Australia. The mysterious outback murder that shook Australia Police say they will not stop searching for Peter Falconio's remains, after the man convicted of his murder died. An Indigenous Australian community is fighting to protect sacred springs from a coal mine One Aboriginal family has been fighting for nearly a decade to protect the Doongmabulla Springs. 'You did it': How doctor realised mushroom cook was a killer Erin Patterson was found guilty of murdering three relatives with a toxic mushroom lunch. title: Europe | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Europe Violent Channel smuggling gang's French and UK network exposed by undercover BBC investigation Exclusive: Secret filming reveals smugglers' forest hideout and cash deals at UK train station. 15 hrs ago Europe Zelensky thanks Trump for 'productive' talks ahead of ceasefire deadline US envoy Steve Witkoff will visit Moscow on Wednesday, as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine looms. 12 hrs ago Europe Putin and Trump's relationship has soured - but behind the posturing, a Ukraine deal is still possible Steve Witkoff is visiting Moscow this week - is it a sign that an agreement between Russia and the US to end the fighting in Ukraine could yet be reached? 1 day ago BBC InDepth Cooper won't put a number on migrant returns to France The "one-in, one-out" deal, which starts tomorrow, will see some of those arriving in the UK returned to France. 14 hrs ago Europe Irish missionary and child, 3, among nine kidnapped from Haiti orphanage Gena Heraty and a three-year-old child were taken in the middle of the night in a "planned act", officials say. 1 day ago World Zelensky thanks Trump for 'productive' talks ahead of ceasefire deadline US envoy Steve Witkoff will visit Moscow on Wednesday, as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine looms. 12 hrs ago Europe German spy trial of far-right MP's former aide begins The man is accused of spying for China and using his role as an assistant to AfD politician Maximilian Krah to gather information. 13 hrs ago World Former Romanian President Ion Iliescu dies aged 95 He was Romania's first freely elected leader after communism fell in 1989, and later faced charges of crimes against humanity. 14 hrs ago Europe Putin and Trump's relationship has soured - but behind the posturing, a Ukraine deal is still possible Steve Witkoff is visiting Moscow this week - is it a sign that an agreement between Russia and the US to end the fighting in Ukraine could yet be reached? 1 day ago BBC InDepth Kremlin plays down Trump's nuclear rhetoric as US envoy set to visit Moscow The comments come as Trump's deadline for Russia to agree a ceasefire with Ukraine or face sanctions edges closer. Eurostar passengers face delays and cancellations due to French rail issue Several services between London and Paris were impacted, as were some trains between Amsterdam and Brussels. Watch: Twin waterspouts merge near Italian coastline A local tour boat operator paused an excursion so he could film the waterspouts off Italy's east coast. Danish zoo asks for unwanted pets to feed its predators Aalborg Zoo says the unique scheme is aimed at mimicking what its predators would eat in the wild. Ukraine officials held in military drone corruption probe The arrests come just two days after Ukraine's anti-corruption agencies had their independence restored. Features & Analysis Ion Iliescu: Romania's first democratic leader with a divisive legacy His three terms saw the tumultuous birth of modern Romania as it moved from communism to democracy. Melting glaciers threaten to wipe out European villages - is the steep cost to protect them worth it? Switzerland spends almost $500m a year on protective structures. Is it worth it - or, as some suggest, should people move away from the mountain villages at risk? They escaped Ukraine's front lines. The sound of drones followed them As technology transforms the war in Ukraine, soldiers are experiencing a new form of trauma: "Droneophobia". Confusion and anger in Switzerland - hit by highest tariffs in Europe Trump threatened Switzerland with 31% tariffs but they ended up even higher, leaving the country asking why. EU-US tariff deal not finished yet, say Europeans unhappy with Trump's terms Discrepancies between the two sides' version of the deal have emerged, and key details of the agreement are yet to be negotiated. Watch/Listen Watch: Twin waterspouts merge near Italian coastline A local tour boat operator paused an excursion so he could film the waterspouts off Italy's east coast. Watch: Russian volcano erupts after more than 500 years Huge plumes of smoke could be seen rising into the sky above the Krasheninnikov Volcano. Huge explosion rocks Russian oil facility The strike was one of several Ukraine said it carried out against Russian military infrastructure. Marchand breaks Lochte's 200m medley world record Watch as France's Leon Marchand breaks 200m medley world record in one minute 52.69 seconds to beat the previous best of 1:54.00 set by Ryan Lochte. Watch: Major earthquake off Russia triggers widespread tsunami warnings Tsunami warnings have been issued in Russia, Japan, Ecuador and Hawaii. Latest updates 7 hrs ago How Trump's secondary tariffs on Russia could hit the global economy The sweeping secondary tariffs could cut the flow of Russian oil and gas to global markets. 7 hrs ago 9 hrs ago Family of Irish missionary kidnapped in Haiti 'devastated' Gena Heraty, from County Mayo, was taken with eight other p

title: Latin America | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Latin America Irish missionary and child, 3, among nine kidnapped from Haiti orphanage Gena Heraty and a three-year-old child were taken in the middle of the night in a "planned act", officials say. 1 day ago World Chile rescuers find body of last trapped miner - five confirmed dead Tunnels in a copper mine collapsed after an earthquake on Thursday, trapping five miners and killing a sixth person that day. 2 days ago Latin America Twelve years house arrest for Colombian ex-leader Álvaro Uribe The 73-year-old is the first ex-president in Colombia's history to be convicted of a crime. 4 days ago Latin America Why Trump's tariffs on Brazil are more about political retaliation than trade Trump has set a whopping 50% tariff on Brazilian goods - one of the highest rates yet levied by the US. 6 days ago World Trump hits Brazil with 50% tariffs and sanctions judge in Bolsonaro case The US also imposed a 50% tariff on Brazil after Trump accused it of "attacks" on US companies and of conducting a "witch hunt" against Bolsonaro. 6 days ago World Chile rescuers find body of last trapped miner - five confirmed dead Tunnels in a copper mine collapsed after an earthquake on Thursday, trapping five miners and killing a sixth person that day. 2 days ago Latin America Mission begins to save snails threatened by own beauty Researchers in Cuba and the UK are working together to reveal the biological secrets of the beautiful but endangered Polymita snail. 2 days ago Science & Environment Their children can't eat, speak or walk - so forgotten Zika mothers raise them together We speak to the women infected with the Zika virus in Brazil a decade ago about what life is like with their children now. 3 days ago Latin America Twelve years house arrest for Colombian ex-leader Álvaro Uribe The 73-year-old is the first ex-president in Colombia's history to be convicted of a crime. 4 days ago Latin America Features & Analysis 'We lived through hell,' say Venezuelans released from mega-prison in El Salvador Four men deported from the US to a notorious facility in El Salvador tell the BBC after their release they were mistreated. In a Haitian city ruled by gangs, young rape survivor raises baby she was told to abort Helene, abducted aged 17, is among thousands of women attacked as gang violence spreads in Haiti. Skeleton in Guatemalan jungle likely US birdwatcher missing since 2023 Clothes matching those of Raymond Ashcroft, who disappeared while visiting Maya ruins, were found at the scene. How the rise of green tech is feeding another environmental crisis The world's race to decarbonise has led to the rise of electric cars - and with it, soaring demand for lithium, which is required for the batteries The deepening water shortage row between the US and Mexico The US is accusing its southern neighbour of breaking a long-held water sharing agreement. Watch/Listen Watch: US builds new wall at Mexico border The new section is part of a plan to close 'critical' gaps in the border wall and enhance security operations. Hurricane Erick hits Mexico resort towns killing two Video shows communities in the affected areas dealing with flood waters and a messy clean-up. Watch: Moment people flee church as earthquake interrupts mass in Peru The 5.6 magnitude earthquake struck near Lima, Peru on Sunday morning, causing panic at the city's cathedral. Shakira: For an immigrant in the US, it means living in constant fear Watch: 'It's important' - LA protesters on why they're taking to the streets Demonstrations have continued in other major US cities, including Chicago, where protesters clashed with police on Tuesday. Latest updates 1 day ago US condemns house arrest of Brazil's ex-president Jair Bolsonaro US State Department responded to Brazil's supreme court order saying Bolsonaro allegedly breached a ban on using social media. 1 day ago 2 days ago Chile rescuers find body of last trapped miner - five confirmed dead Tunnels in a copper mine collapsed after an earthquake on Thursday, trapping five miners and killing a sixth person that day. 2 days ago 3 days ago Their children can't eat, speak or walk - so forgotten Zika mothers raise them together We speak to the women infected with the Zika virus in Brazil a decade ago about what life is like with their children now. 3 days ago 4 days ago Twelve years house arrest for Colombian ex-leader Álvaro Uribe The 73-year-old is the first ex-president in Colombia's history to be convicted of a crime. 4 days ago 5 days ago Sandstorm turns skies bright orange in Peru Footage from Ica shows huge dust clouds. 5 days ago 5 days ago El Salvador scraps term limits, paving way for Bukele to rule indefinitely The reforms will extend term times to six years, while the next election will be brought forward to 2027. 5 days ago 7 days ago New Brazil development law risks Amazon deforestation, UN expert warns A new environmental licensing law has been criticised by environmentalists as Brazil prepares for COP30. 7 day

title: Middle East | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News Middle East Netanyahu to propose full reoccupation of Gaza, Israeli media report The plan will involve a complete takeover of Gaza, but reportedly faces opposition from military chiefs. 16 hrs ago Middle East He is a human skeleton, Gaza hostage's brother tells BBC Ilay David says the Hamas video showing his brother Evyatar emaciated and weak is a "new form of cruelty" that has left his parents shattered. 2 days ago Middle East Dozens of migrants die in boat capsize off Yemen Dozens are missing after a boat carrying more than 150 migrants, many believed to be Ethiopian, sank in bad weather. 2 days ago World 'Thank you, but it's too late': Why some Palestinians aren't convinced by Starmer's promise Some say Britain's decision is an important first step – while others worry it won't make a real difference, writes BBC's International Editor Jeremy Bowen. 4 days ago BBC InDepth Israeli minister sparks anger by praying at sensitive Jerusalem holy site Far-right minister Itamar Ben-Gvir prayed at Jerusalem's al-Aqsa mosque compound, violating a decades-old arrangement. 3 days ago Middle East He is a human skeleton, Gaza hostage's brother tells BBC Ilay David says the Hamas video showing his brother Evyatar emaciated and weak is a "new form of cruelty" that has left his parents shattered. 2 days ago Middle East Hundreds of Israeli ex-officials appeal to Trump to help end Gaza war It comes amid reports that PM Netanyahu is pushing to expand Israel's military operations in Gaza. 2 days ago Middle East World leaders condemn videos of emaciated Israeli hostages in Gaza as Red Cross calls for access Hamas said it would allow Red Cross access if humanitarian aid corridors were opened into Gaza. 2 days ago Middle East Dozens of migrants die in boat capsize off Yemen Dozens are missing after a boat carrying more than 150 migrants, many believed to be Ethiopian, sank in bad weather. 2 days ago World Aid group says worker killed by Israeli military in attack on Gaza HQ The Palestine Red Crescent Society accuses Israel of a "direct" strike - Israel says it is reviewing the claim. Family condemns Hamas video showing emaciated Israeli hostage Evyatar David's family says Hamas is starving him, as the group shows a video of him being kept in a tunnel. Hamas refuses to disarm until Palestinian state established Negotiations between Israel and Hamas for a ceasefire and the release of hostages stalled last week. Trump envoy visits controversial Gaza aid distribution site The visit with the IDF follows near daily reports of deadly shootings in the vicinity of the sites. France suspends Gaza evacuations after student antisemitism row The Palestinian student, who arrived in France in July, has had her university accreditation withdrawn. Features Gazan boy first to be treated in UK for war injuries Majd, 15, was almost killed by an Israeli tank shell last February. He has finally arrived in the UK for reconstructive surgery. US allies break with Trump to force diplomatic shift on Gaza As Canada joins France and the UK with plans to recognise a Palestinian state, the US stands firmly with Israel - but does Trump have a long-term plan for Gaza's future? The Gulf bets big on AI as it seeks the 'new oil' The UAE and Saudi Arabia are partnering with the US to position themselves as AI hubs. Gaza aid site offered a 'women only' day. It didn't stop the killing Families say mothers Mary Sheikh al-Eid and Khadija Abu Anza were shot while seeking aid from GHF station in southern Gaza. He went to get aid and didn't come back - stories of people killed in Gaza As aid agencies warn of "mass starvation", the BBC hears from the relatives of some of those killed in the past week. Watch/Listen Two girls shot in Gaza - BBC pieces together what happened and looks at dozens more child shootings Layan and Mira were killed in proximity to IDF soldiers - the Israeli military says intentional harm to civilians is prohibited and their cases will be examined by the authorities. Gazan mother of malnourished baby speaks to BBC Yasmeen Abu Sultan says her two-month old daughter is suffering from malnutrition and asked that she is taken out of Gaza to undertake medical treatment. Relative of hostage responds to declarations of Palestinian statehood Dalia Cusnir tells the BBC "the only way of securing the future of the region" is to return the hostages and force Hamas to down weapons. Watch: How did Gaza get to the brink of starvation? The BBC's diplomatic correspondent Paul Adams explains how the people of Gaza have reached a point of starvation. BBC presses UK foreign secretary on timing of recognising Palestinian state Prime Minister Keir Starmer says the plan will go ahead unless the Israeli government takes "substantive steps to end the appalling situation in Gaza". Latest updates 1 hr ago UN official says Israel expanding Gaza operations would risk 'catastrophic consequences' The UN's assistant secretary general says reports of the possible move are

title: In Pictures | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body:
News News In Pictures Ballet and bioluminescence: Africa's top shots A selection of the week's best photos from across the African continent and beyond. 5 days ago Africa Sporting photos of the week A selection of some of the most striking sports photographs taken around the world over the past seven days. 8 days ago Book of unseen Live Aid photos published The 1985 event at Wembley stadium was attended by 72,000 people. 19 Jul 2025 Hampshire & Isle of Wight Euro 2025: Photos of the group stage A selection of some of the most striking photographs taken at Euro 2025 during the group stage. 15 Jul 2025 Women's Football Buck Moon captured across the South Images of July's Buck Moon sent to us from Oxfordshire, Dorset, Hampshire and the Isle of Wight. 11 Jul 2025 England Sporting photos of the week A selection of some of the most striking sports photographs taken around the world over the past seven days. 8 days ago President Trump's private visit to Scotland Trump played a round of golf at Turnberry on Saturday while hundreds of protesters gathered in Aberdeen and Edinburgh. 7 days ago Glasgow & West Scotland Photographer celebrates fishing town's life at sea Peter Robinson shares his photographs of the North Shields fishing fleet taken over 10 years. 22 Jul 2025 Tyne Book of unseen Live Aid photos published The 1985 event at Wembley stadium was attended by 72,000 people. 19 Jul 2025 Hampshire & Isle of Wight Features Photographer showcases her work at French Celtic Festival Joann Randles' photography will be at display at the world's largest Celtic gathering. Legendary photographer Sebastião Salgado dies at 81 He was known for dramatic and unflinching black-and-white images of hardship, conflict and natural beauty. Photographer spends decade capturing back garden wildlife Andrew Fusek Peters has spent a decade capturing the images in a celebration of Britain's wildife. Candles, wreaths, famous faces: VE Day at 80 in pictures Events are taking place across the UK to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of World War Two in Europe. 2025 Sony World Photography Awards: Winners revealed Sony Photography Awards winner explores the tension between artificial spaces and environmental destruction. title: BBC InDepth - In depth and expert analysis from BBC News
body:
News News BBC InDepth Carol Kirkwood: Why weather forecasters (like me) often appear to get it wrong The accuracy of forecasting has improved enormously - and AI promises further advances. But there are certain challenges in finding ways to share that mass of data with viewers Putin and Trump's relationship has soured - but behind the posturing, a Ukraine deal is still possible Steve Witkoff is visiting Moscow this week - is it a sign that an agreement between Russia and the US to end the fighting in Ukraine could yet be reached? 1 day ago BBC InDepth Hackers, secret cables and security fears: The explosive fight over China's new embassy in the UK It will be the biggest embassy in Europe, if approved. But its opponents fear it brings with it certain risks and dangers 2 days ago BBC InDepth 'Thank you, but it's too late': Why some Palestinians aren't convinced by Starmer's promise Some say Britain's decision is an important first step – while others worry it won't make a real difference, writes BBC's International Editor Jeremy Bowen. 4 days ago BBC InDepth What screen time does to children's brains is more complicated than it seems Screen time has become synonymous with bad news - but the science may not be as straightforward as it seems 6 days ago BBC InDepth Why plane turbulence is becoming more frequent - and more severe Flights are getting bumpier, thanks in part to climate change. But new studies are looking into innovative potential ways to turbulence-proof wings - using AI and owls 7 days ago BBC InDepth Hackers, secret cables and security fears: The explosive fight over China's new embassy in the UK It will be the biggest embassy in Europe, if approved. But its opponents fear it brings with it certain risks and dangers 2 days ago BBC InDepth Melting glaciers threaten to wipe out European villages - is the steep cost to protect them worth it? Switzerland spends almost $500m a year on protective structures. Is it worth it - or, as some suggest, should people move away from the mountain villages at risk? 3 days ago BBC InDepth Trump's global tariffs 'victory' may well come at a high price The US president considers it a win - but if this all triggers a foundational realignment, the results may not break in his favour 5 days ago BBC InDepth 'Thank you, but it's too late': Why some Palestinians aren't convinced by Starmer's promise Some say Britain's decision is an important first step – while others worry it won't make a real difference, writes BBC's International Editor Jeremy Bowen. 4 days ago BBC InDepth The rise of Japan's far right was supercharged by Trump - and tourists ‘Sanseito says what others are thinking’: Why a once-obscure far-right party shook up Japan's political scene How reality TV changed the way we think - for the better When the first series of Big Brother launched, one critic denounced it as a "smearing of excrement" over TV screens. So, exactly 25 years on, how has reality TV affected viewers? The struggle for control of the Arctic is accelerating - and riskier than ever The debate: Will the new rules for pornography sites do more harm than good? How Trump is using the courts to get what he wants - and changing the shape of presidential power Trump's confrontations with the courts are unique in their scale and fury, compared with those of past presidents Best of Sounds The Briefing Room David Aaronovitch and guests discuss identity cards. Understand Tim Hayward looks at the science, culture, history - and future - of psychedelics. Rory Stewart: The Long History of... Rory Stewart explores ideas of the hero through time. The Briefing Room Is Labour's promise of 'an improved and ambitious relationship' with Europe coming true? Best of iPlayer What Happened at...? Eighty years after the first atomic bomb used in war, Jordan Dunbar hears from survivors. Chloe Ayling: My Unbelievable Kidnapping Chloe Ayling recounts her 2017 kidnapping and how it changed her life. Panorama Why did so many take part in the riots that followed the Southport attack of July 2024? BBC News From rock star to reality TV, fans and friends reflect on Ozzy Osbourne's life and career.

title: BBC Verify | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body: News News BBC Verify Despite Trump's peace calls, Russian attacks on Ukraine double since inauguration Missile and drone attacks on Ukraine are now higher than at any other point of the war, according to Ukrainian data. 7 hrs ago World The US-EU trade deal in numbers - how it compares to UK deal Donald Trump has struck an agreement with the European Union to reduce tariffs - what will that mean for the UK? 28 Jul 2025 BBC Verify ​​What is inside the GHF food aid box being distributed in Gaza? BBC Verify examines the meals handed out to Gazans - and why their nutritional value is questioned by some experts. 25 Jul 2025 Middle East Camp Mystic: Why were so many people killed there during Texas floods? The recent floods in Kerr County, Texas killed 135 people, including many young children. 22 Jul 2025 US & Canada Gaza war: Is the UK selling arms to Israel? The UK suspended dozens of arms licences to Israel last year, but many say the measures do not go far enough. 22 Jul 2025 Middle East The US-EU trade deal in numbers - how it compares to UK deal Donald Trump has struck an agreement with the European Union to reduce tariffs - what will that mean for the UK? 28 Jul 2025 BBC Verify Gaza war: Is the UK selling arms to Israel? The UK suspended dozens of arms licences to Israel last year, but many say the measures do not go far enough. 22 Jul 2025 Middle East Investigations North Korea's Benidorm-style resort welcomes first Russian tourists Details of how it was built - in a country largely closed to the outside world - are shrouded in secrecy. Russian naval ship 'disguised' itself while passing through English Channel The Boikiy emitted a fake ID signal while sailing through the waterway alongside two sanctioned oil tankers. Iran’s secretive nuclear site that only a US bomb could hit A visual guide to Fordo - the enrichment plant entombed in a mountainside south of Tehran. Israeli army admits to Gaza strike after BBC Verify investigation At least one Palestinian was killed and 30 others injured in the Israeli strike on tents in Khan Younis on Sunday, medics say. How controversial US-Israeli backed Gaza aid plan turned to chaos Touted as a vital lifeline for Gazans facing  starvation, the first week of the new plan has been beset by chaos. BBC Verify Live Tuesday 5 August: Verified video shows India town hit by flooding Latest updates from the BBC's specialists in fact-checking, verifying video and tackling disinformation. Monday 4 August: Russian TikToker fined over video and 'wealthy exodus' fact-checked Latest updates from the BBC's specialists in fact-checking, verifying video and tackling disinformation. Friday 1 August: Analysing blasts in Ukraine and armed men on Gaza aid trucks Latest updates from the BBC's specialists in fact-checking, verifying video and tackling disinformation. Thursday 31 July: BBC Verify Live: Strikes in Ukraine and Russian AI network Latest updates from the BBC's specialists in fact-checking, verifying video and tackling disinformation. Wednesday 30 July: How we’re verifying earthquake video and analysing Gaza aid situation Latest updates from the BBC's specialists in fact-checking, verifying video and tackling disinformation. Disinformation Israel-Iran conflict unleashes wave of AI disinformation Fake AI videos relating to the conflict have gained over 100 million views online, BBC Verify finds. Misleading posts obtaining millions of views on X BBC Verify has debunked videos which purport to show Pakistani attacks on Indian bases and jets crashing. BBC Verify: Earthquake video proven fake gets millions of views BBC Verify: Earthquake video proven fake gets millions of views BBC Verify: Viral Donald Trump Jr audio highly likely AI fake A clip of Donald Trump Jr allegedly saying on his podcast that the US should have sent arms to Russia rather than Ukraine was very likely generated with AI, experts say. What an AI-generated video of Gaza reveals about Trump tactics Ros Atkins on... Ros Atkins on... How close is Iran to a nuclear weapon? Israel's Prime Minister has long warned that Iran is close to developing nuclear weapons. BBC Verify's Ros Atkins explains what we know about its programme. Ros Atkins on… the UK's changing energy mix Ros Atkins looks at the reasons behind the government's investment in nuclear power, and how its plan fits into the UK’s energy mix. Ros Atkins on... Ukraine's Operation 'Spider's Web' BBC Analysis Editor Ros Atkins and the BBC Verify team build up a picture of what happened and how it was done. Ros Atkins on... The White House claims on BBC Gaza coverage Ros Atkins from BBC Verify takes a look at the facts surrounding remarks that came our of Washington. US politics Did US government cuts contribute to the Texas tragedy? Following the Texas floods some Democrats have warned about the "consequences" of President Trump's cuts to the federal workforce. Fact-checking three key claims about Trump's mega-bill Trump insists that the new bill will save the US b

title: BBC
body:
Executive Lounge The ex-Google exec who wants to simplify your life Marissa Mayer, a former Google and Yahoo executive, believes AI should simplify our lives. See more How one product made a multi-million dollar brand Nell Diamond, CEO of Hill House Home, shares how her small business skyrocketed to global success with the launch of the Nap Dress in 2019. The business of transforming mental health at work Cherie Clonan, CEO of The Digital Picnic, explains how free dinners, burnout-preventing days off and even ADHD assessments have boosted employee wellbeing – and her bottom line. How Duolingo became so addicting, according to its CEO Perhaps no app has mastered user loyalty quite like Duolingo, the gamified language-learning platform 34 million people a day can't put down. How Microsoft is tackling AI bias Microsoft is turning to AI to make its workplace more inclusive Why Zoom wants you to go back to the office Zoom chief product officer Smita Hashim explains why even video-chat innovators need the physical space – with a little help from AI. Lego's CEO on the business case for play As digital innovation reshapes the toy market, the BBC's Executive Lounge meets with Lego's Chief Executive, Niels B Christiansen. Mastercard exec Shamina Singh on the 'missing middle' of small businesses Today in the Executive Lounge, one global firm's innovative solutions to the universal problem of small businesses struggling to survive. data-driven answers in the dark. 8 Mar 2024 26 Feb 2024 Amazon MGM's playbook for inclusive film and TV Latasha Gillespie, head of global DEI and accessibility at Amazon MGM Studios, enters the BBC's Executive Lounge to talk about inclusivity in entertainment. 26 Feb 2024 15 Feb 2024 Google's chief diversity officer on why companies should 're-recruit' their top talent every day Melonie Parker title: Technology of Business | Latest News & Updates | BBC News
body:
Technology of Business Will new greener brake pads be more expensive? Automotive industry will have to change techniques and materials as new EU rules come into force in 2026 1 day ago Do you feel lucky plank? Meet the new 'bulletproof' wood New ways are being found to make wood even stronger and more versatile in construction. 5 days ago Trucking's uneasy relationship with new tech Matching trucks with cargo has become digitised, adding efficiency, but driving down earnings. 21 Jul 2025 Spud-tacular: How India became a french fry superpower India's position as a leading exporter of french fries has spurred innovation on potato farms. 17 Jul 2025 Asia Heat pump makers are ready for a rush: Will customers come? Heat pump makers are ready to raise output, but demand is still sluggish. 14 Jul 2025 Do you feel lucky plank? Meet the new 'bulletproof' wood New ways are being found to make wood even stronger and more versatile in construction. 5 days ago Could aluminium become the packaging 'champion'? Some packaging firms say aluminium could be used more widely in packaging, but cost may hold it back 28 Jul 2025 Business Artificial food colours are out, so what's next? Big food firms are phasing out artificial colours, so tech firms are rushing to fill the gap. 24 Jul 2025 Technology Trucking's uneasy relationship with new tech Matching trucks with cargo has become digitised, adding efficiency, but driving down earnings. 21 Jul 2025 'Autofocus' specs promise sharp vision, near or far Start-up firms and researchers are working on lenses that can change their focus. Why little Lithuania has big plans for space tech Lithuania has a promising space tech sector, but it wants more government support. The bridge changing lives and boosting business The Öresund bridge, which connects Denmark and Sweden, is celebrating 25 years since its opening. Should we be letting flies eat our food waste? In Lithuania and Australia, hungry fly larvae are used to process food waste into useful protein. Supercell boss: 'We need to take bigger risks' The boss of mobile gaming giant Supercell says the industry needs to take bigger risks to compete. Tech giants unleash AI on weather forecasts: are they any good? The biggest tech firms are using AI to forecast the weather but is that better than existing models? Why Ukraine is one of the world's most digital countries Despite the war, Ukraine has developed of the most advanced systems for digital government services. Indian scientists search for the perfect apple India can't grow enough apples to meet demand but farmers are struggling to raise production. From festivals to weddings: Why drone shows are booming Light shows involving hundreds and even thousands of drones are becoming big attractions. Why food firms are scrambling to cut down on ingredients Food firms are marketing ranges with fewer ingredients, but are they healthier? title: BBC Business | Future of Business
body: Future of Business MP becomes first to create himself as an AI bot Mark Sewards MP says the chatbot version of himself will allow people to ask for help with local issues. See more Artificial intelligence 'Facial recognition tech mistook me for wanted man' Shaun Thompson is challenging the Met Police's use of live facial recognition technology. Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. Health minister visits GP surgery using AI for notes The surgery was commended by the health minister for using AI to try to make healthcare more efficient. AI scam targets islanders with fake minister posts Deputy Lindsay de Sausmarez advised islanders to warn vulnerable people the posts were fraudulent. Cambridge United to use AI for player contracts The League Two club say the move will help cut costs and improve turnaround times. AI physio app halves wait list for back pain treatment in UK About 2,500 hours of clinician time is saved during the app's three-month trial, the NHS says. Watch Playing with FIRE: How to quit work and retire in your 30s A personal finance strategy popular among millennials is helping them to quit their job and retire decades early. 23 Apr 2024 Future of business Boomerang CEOs: Do they ever succeed? We rethink solo working and explore the future of work-life. 14 Nov 2023 Future of business Can supersonic flight ever be sustainable? How a new era of quiet, net zero supersonic airliners could revolutionise the aviation industry. 14 Nov 2023 Future of business Commencement speech: The surprising pitfall of your passions Students are graduating in the US this week. The commencement speeches might lead them into questionable choices. 14 Nov 2023 Future of business Executive Lounge The ex-Google exec who wants to simplify your life Marissa Mayer, a former Google and Yahoo executive, believes AI should simplify our lives. Will new greener brake pads be more expensive? Automotive industry will have to change techniques and materials as new EU rules come into force in 2026 Explaining how a touchscreen works with a sausage British mathematician Hannah Fry digs into the science of touchscreens. Tech manufacturing has powered Asia - now it's a casualty of Trump's tariffs Trump's tariffs in his first term took aim at China - but this time they are going beyond. Sustainable business Farmer installs solar panels on part of land Rob Hadley says solar panels installed on his farm is providing energy for up to 16,000 homes. Sperrins wind farm gets go-ahead after appeal The application to build six turbines at Magheramore near Dungiven was rejected by the council in 2023. Watch Moment 'air scooter' fails Channel crossing attempt The drone-like contraption flew from Sangatte and neared the cliffs of Dover before splashing down. 26 Jul 2025 Business 'We bought our first home with another couple' Two couples struggling to afford London prices bought a flat together. Add two babies and how is it going? 18 Jul 2025 Business Post Office scandal victims' message to Keir Starmer "Just stop being cruel to people", one victim says. 9 Jul 2025 Business Watch: Post Office scandal victims demand accountability Seema Misra and Janet Skinner share their feelings of pain and call for accountability in the Post Office scandal. 8 Jul 2025 Business BBC correspondent questions Trump over US beef exports The UK says it will maintain food standards which lock out some types of American beef and chicken. 8 May 2025 Business Why US markets skyrocketed after Trump tariffs pause The S&P 500 index soared 9.5% in the biggest one-day rally since 2008, following days of turmoil sparked by the tariffs. 9 Apr 2025 Business Starmer says UK will keep 'cool head' after tariff announcement The prime minister told the UK's biggest business leaders a trade war with the US is not in the UK's national interest. 3 Apr 2025 Business Three things to know about Trump's tariffs announcement The BBC's Michelle Fleury breaks down what the import taxes mean for the US and countries around the world. 3 Apr 2025 Business BBC Verify: How did Rachel Reeves make her sums add up? title: BBC Innovation | Technology
body: Technology Why Pac-Man remains a beloved icon The yellow eating machine revolutionised video games 45 years ago. What has made Pac-Man and his adventures so addictive? Latest headlines MP becomes first to create himself as an AI bot Mark Sewards MP says the chatbot version of himself will allow people to ask for help with local issues. 'Facial recognition tech mistook me for wanted man' Shaun Thompson is challenging the Met Police's use of live facial recognition technology. Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. Will new greener brake pads be more expensive? Automotive industry will have to change techniques and materials as new EU rules come into force in 2026 Tesla awards boss Elon Musk $29bn in shares Tesla's board hopes to retain Elon Musk amid a fight for tech talent in the sector. Explaining how a touchscreen works with a sausage British mathematician Hannah Fry digs into the science of touchscreens. Green Tech The seawall being built in Japan's turtle haven Some locals and ecologists are troubled by the potential impacts a looming seawall could have on the biodiverse Japanese island of Amami Ōshima. See more Analysis and features Jobs in video games dried up, so we made our own Getting work in gaming is harder and harder, especially for new starters. How are young developers following their passions? My journey to the heart of the forgotten internet Slowly but surely, huge swaths of the internet are vanishing. But the artefacts of the early web are still out there, and they have lessons for the future. Tech manufacturing has powered Asia - now it's a casualty of Trump's tariffs Trump's tariffs in his first term took aim at China - but this time they are going beyond. Do you feel lucky, plank? Meet the new 'bulletproof' wood New ways are being found to make wood even stronger and more versatile in construction. Watch Building's hard problem: Can concrete go green? Tech Now visits a Dutch startup producing a more sustainable alternative to concrete. 5 days ago Tech Now High-tech tools cracking the case of Chile's lost children Tech Now visits organisations in Chile using innovative tech to track down missing relatives. 25 Jul 2025 Tech Now Bringing a baby dinosaur roar to 'life' BBC journalist Tom Gerken voices his own dinosaur in the game Jurassic World Evolution 3. 18 Jul 2025 Tech Now Why China is winning the global EV race Tech Now visits China to test drive Xpeng's newest EV car model on the streets of Guangzhou. 11 Jul 2025 Tech Now The observatory that can reveal the deepest secrets of space Tech Now is given rare access to the world's most advanced telescope with the largest digital camera ever built. 4 Jul 2025 Tech Now What it takes to write like Agatha Christie We explore how technology is reviving the renowned fiction writer's legacy. 28 Jun 2025 Tech Now The science behind brewing tastier non-alcoholic beer UK brewery Wiper and True shows the BBC's Tech Now team a pioneering technique to craft alcohol-free beer. 20 Jun 2025 Tech Now Moment SpaceX rocket explodes into massive fireball A live stream has captured the moment a SpaceX Starship rocket exploded when preparing for a flight test in Texas on Wednesday. 19 Jun 2025 Technology How 'griefbots' allow people to 'talk to the dead' Tech Now explores the growing trend of 'griefbots' or 'deadbots' that allow people to 'talk to the dead'. 13 Jun 2025 Tech Now What's happening with Trump's Tesla parked at White House? The US president is considering selling his Tesla car - which he says he purchased when he was trying to help Musk promote his company. 6 Jun 2025 Technology Inside one of the world's most advanced supercomputers BBC Tech Now explores how the latest generation of high-performance computing stays cool. 6 Jun 2025 Tech Now Fans queue overnight for the launch of the Nintendo Switch 2 Nintendo's long-awaited Switch 2 has been released worldwide. 5 Jun 2025 Technology How to cure your flying fears It's safer than ever to fly - so why does air-travel anxiety seem so hard to overcome? 5 Jun 2025 Technology Never-before-seen images of our Universe Inside the world’s largest digital camera revealing unseen corners of our Universe. 30 May 2025 Tech Now An inside look at how the Internet Archive saves the web BBC reporter Lily Jamali heads behind the scenes of the non-profit organisation in San Francisco. 26 May 2025 Tech Now The machine aiming to recreate the sun's energy Meet the 24-year-old who convinced former Pentagon officials to join his nuclear fusion project. 14 May 2025 Tech Now Watch how rare sperm is found in IVF lab We go inside a New York City lab developing new tech to increase IVF success rates for patients. 3 May 2025 Tech Now A reporter's quest for the perfect fragrance An immersive experience floating through a 'scent galaxy' offers a different sense of reality. 24 Apr 2025 Tech No

title: BBC Innovation | Artificial Intelligence
body: Artificial Intelligence MP becomes first to create himself as an AI bot Mark Sewards MP says the chatbot version of himself will allow people to ask for help with local issues. Chinese nationals charged with exporting Nvidia AI chips to China Chuan Geng and Shiwei Yang are accused of exporting the chips from the US to China through Singapore and Malaysia. Health minister visits GP surgery using AI for notes The surgery was commended by the health minister for using AI to try to make healthcare more efficient. British 999 call handler's voice cloned by Russian network using AI A BBC Verify investigation has revealed that the identities of British public sector workers have been cloned using AI by a Russian-linked disinformation campaign. AI physio app halves wait list for back pain treatment in UK About 2,500 hours of clinician time is saved during the app's three-month trial, the NHS says. Meta profits surge helps drive Zuckerberg’s AI ambitions The Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp-owner is pumping billions of dollars into artificial intelligence projects.
