title: Opinion | The Guardian
body: Opinion Comment is free… but facts are sacred CP Scott, 1921 Guardian editor We’re being deafened by digital noise. Pause it and you hear the sound of democracy in crisis Rafael Behr Step offline for just a moment and you see how democratic politics is struggling to cope with the pace of technological change 2h ago … … comments We published a photo of a malnourished child in Gaza. It made an impact globally – and created controversy Elisabeth Ribbans Initially, we did not know that Muhammad Zakariya Ayyoub al-Matouq had cerebral palsy. But his medical details do not diminish his suffering, or that of other children in Gaza, says Guardian global readers’ editor Elisabeth Ribbans 51m ago The EU is a colossus. So why is it cowering before Trump like a mouse? Alexander Hurst 3h ago Jeans, controversy, used bathwater: Sydney Sweeney’s selling it all. A showbiz masterclass, if you ask me Marina Hyde Brexit has been a resounding disaster. Starmer must find the courage to change course Ed Davey … … comments Moral outrage over Bonnie Blue’s porn empire misses the point: this is hardcore economics Gaby Hinsliff The west ignores Rwanda’s dark side – and political prisoners like my mother pay the price Rémy Amahirwa Pushing airport expansion while rail travel languishes – so much for Labour’s green agenda Polly Toynbee … … comments Poland is sliding back towards populism. Democrats elsewhere should heed our mistakes Karolina Wigura and Jarosław Kuisz … … comments The real danger in this permacrisis is not the political drama: it’s the risk that nothing changes Nesrine Malik … … comments All opinion Facebook Write for us Cartoon Hide Stephen Lillie on Labour’s small boats distraction – cartoon The government has announced yet another policy pledge on immigration, promising to spend an extra £100m on measures to deter Channel crossings … … comments The housing crisis in Europe Hide A broken housing market is driving inequality right across Europe – and fuelling the far right Kirsty Major … … comments Vienna has been declared a renters’ utopia – here’s why Justin Kadi … … comments Across Europe, the financial sector has pushed up house prices. It’s a political timebomb Tim White … … comments Budapest’s young people are joining the ranks of generation rent Csaba Jelinek … … comments How to beat the far right Hide A lesson from Brazil – where gig workers have rallied against the right Rodrigo Nunes … … comments What can the global left learn from Mexico – where far-right politics hasn’t taken off? Thomas Graham In Slovakia, our grassroots movement helped oust a neo-Nazi. We can do it again Alexandra Bitušíková What smashed the far right in east London? A playbook that said connect, connect, connect Margaret Hodge The Guardian view Hide The Guardian view on asylum myths: when truth loses, scapegoating takes over Britain’s migrant debate The Guardian view on plastic pollution: global action is desperately needed to deal with this scourge The Guardian view on water boss’s undisclosed bonus: Labour won’t fix a system it won’t confront The Guardian view on Berlin’s ailing club scene: a unique inheritance needs protecting Spotlight Hide Everything the right - and the left – are getting wrong about the Online Safety Act George Billinge New limits on what can be seen online have drawn consternation from Nigel Farage and progressives alike. Yet much of it is based on misinformation, says George Billinge, a former Ofcom policy manager You may have missed Hide Europe’s trade deal with the US was dead on arrival – it needs to be buried. Here’s how to do it Georg Riekeles and Varg Folkman … … comments Reform’s tales of wasteland Britain won’t work. There’s a far larger market for hope Gaby Hinsliff … … comments Wes Streeting’s divide and rule tactics may have won against the doctors – but more strikes are coming Polly Smythe … … comments How jigsaws, Lego and sourdough helped the Lionesses win the Euros Amy Izycky Columnists Hide With Trump wreaking havoc, a question for the US Democrats: when will you ever learn? Timothy Garton Ash … … comments Ignore the bluster: as Netanyahu starves Gaza, the world is turning on him – and he knows it Jonathan Freedland Despite the chaos of its launch, Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana’s new party has struck a nerve Andy Beckett … … comments Is this tough US-EU trade deal a triumph for Brexit Britain? Only in leavers’ most delusional fantasies Polly Toynbee … … comments This trade deal is the EU’s Suez moment – its subservience to Trump is on show for all to see Larry Elliott … … comments Critics say Starmer is no Attlee – and they’re right. Labour must look to the future, not the past Martin Kettle … … comments Israel has deliberately starved the people of Gaza. It couldn’t have done it without the west’s help Owen Jones The right wants to kill off the NHS. Striking doctors are playing into their hands Polly Toynbee … … comments Letters Hide Why is ‘Dave from Egham’ so wound up by women’s football? Isr

title: Lifestyle | The Guardian
body:
Lifestyle Sexual healing My wife has had more than 50 sexual partners – so why won’t she sleep with me? After 12 years together, she told me how many people she had slept with before we met. It has made it harder for me to accept how rarely we have sex Pubs ‘A yorkshire pudding like a dishcloth’: how did British pub food get so grim? For many years, UK food had a terrible reputation. Then, in the 1990s, gastropubs brought new flavours, energy and ideas. When and why did it all start to go downhill again? … … comments Dating Hot under the collar: how to ace the dating scene this summer Paid for by This content was paid for by Beconase and produced by the Guardian Labs team. title: Middle East and north Africa | The Guardian
body:
Middle East and north Africa 6 August 2025 Open door We published a photo of a malnourished child in Gaza. It made an impact globally – and created controversy Elisabeth Ribbans Initially, we did not know that Muhammad Zakariya Ayyoub al-Matouq had cerebral palsy. But his medical details do not diminish his suffering, or that of other children in Gaza, says Guardian global readers’ editor Elisabeth Ribbans 07.00 BST 5 August 2025 ‘Healthocide’: experts warn of rise in targeting of health services in conflict 23.30 BST Son of British woman held in Iran speaks to her for first time in 213 days 22.20 BST Ella Baron on Palestine action, proscribed and approved – cartoon 5 Aug 2025 19.07 BST A wasteland of rubble, dust and graves: how Gaza looks from the sky 5 Aug 2025 18.49 BST Israel’s assault on humanitarian norms 5 Aug 2025 18.06 BST How did John Oliver become the moral compass of the US? Arwa Mahdawi 5 Aug 2025 18.02 BST Middle East crisis live Israel-Gaza war: Netanyahu deciding on next steps amid reports he could escalate conflict – as it happened 5 Aug 2025 18.01 BST Gaza before and after: new video shows extent of Israel's destruction – video Video 1:10 Israeli cabinet meeting postponed as tensions rise over Netanyahu’s occupation plan 5 Aug 2025 13.04 BST At least 40 arrested at protest against Gaza war at Trump hotel in New York – video Video 0:45 ‘Heartbreaking’: a London surgeon on the trials of operating in a Gaza hospital 5 Aug 2025 09.40 BST 100 Gaza children hope to be evacuated to UK for urgent medical care 5 Aug 2025 06.00 BST More than 40 arrested at protest against Gaza war at Trump hotel in New York 5 Aug 2025 03.19 BST House Democrats sign on to letter urging Trump to recognise Palestinian statehood 5 Aug 2025 01.13 BST As I sit here in Australia watching Israel starve Palestinians to death, I can’t help but think it could have been me Plestia Alaqad 5 Aug 2025 01.06 BST 4 August 2025 Speaker Mike Johnson visits occupied West Bank to support Israeli settlers 4 Aug 2025 22.11 BST British couple held in Iran moved to separate prisons heightening welfare concerns 4 Aug 2025 21.29 BST How will police respond to rally against Palestine Action ban? 4 Aug 2025 20.00 BST Social media images of Gaza cafes can’t hide truth: Israel is starving Palestinians 4 Aug 2025 18.57 BST About 80,430 results for Middle East and north Africa 1 2 3 4 ...

title: Global development news, investigations and analysis | The Guardian
body: Global development Supported by About this content Photography Women behind the lens: ‘In Venezuela, the culture of pageants goes far beyond beauty’ Photographer Fabiola Ferrero explores her country’s obsession with beauty competitions and how they they are intertwined with politics and oil 49m ago I am one of the last of the Abuelas – the grandmothers still searching for Argentina’s ‘disappeared’. I’m 87, but I will never give up Buscarita Roa Nearly 50 years ago, my son and his wife were tortured and killed and their baby was taken by the military regime. Two decades later, I found her – but hundreds of grandchildren are still missing 2h ago Mexico ‘She stood up to men with machetes’: Sandra Domínguez fought against femicide – then became a victim herself West Africa ‘Well, no, you don’t have to have children’: what African women over the age of 60 have learned about life Mountain climbing Friendship at 13,000 feet: how climbing in the Swiss Alps is bringing refugees together Sheikh Hasina ‘Because of women, it became a people’s revolution’: what has changed one year on from Bangladesh’s student uprising? Tigray Mass rape, forced pregnancy and sexual torture in Tigray amount to crimes against humanity – report US tariffs ‘There’s no work now, just debt’: Cambodian garment workers face precarious future as US tariffs loom Cosmetics Colonial ideas of beauty: how skin-lightening products are linked to cancer in black African women Rock climbing ‘It’s all about trusting yourself, pushing your limits’: Malawi’s first climbers take their sport to new heights All stories Facebook Get the Global Dispatch email Explore Hide ‘Queer people were living, loving, suffering, surviving – but invisible’: west Africa’s groundbreaking gay novel 20 years on Jude Dibia’s Walking With Shadows has a gay character at its heart – a radical act that continues to influence the region’s literary scene Smoking avatars and online games: how big tobacco targets young people in the metaverse Will Mike Waltz lead a ‘full-frontal assault’ on the UN? Young, educated and knee deep in rubbish: the recyclers cleaning up in Cairo’s Garbage City ‘It’s always been some white dude’: how Ethiopia became the world leader in uncovering the story of humankind ‘I didn’t give much thought to the universe’: India’s first astronaut in 40 years inspires next generation of stargazers UNAids chief ‘shaken and disgusted’ by US cuts that will mean millions more deaths Rights and freedom Hide China’s cyber-abuse scandal: is the government unwilling to crack down on exploitation of women online? 6h ago Jobless, homeless and helpless without a man: Afghan women expelled by Iran into hands of the Taliban At home, in school and in hospital: how hundreds of Ukrainian children are dying in Russian attacks Rising number of doctors among hundreds of medical staff detained in Gaza, say rights groups Sudan Hide Sudan’s children face growing threat of deadly infectious diseases as vaccination rates halve Women and girls ‘not safe anywhere’ as Darfur suffers surge in sexual violence ‘Multiple casualties’ reported after attack on UN aid convoy in Darfur Before and after: images by Sudan’s accidental war photographer show loss of everyday life Opinion Hide Trust in the US is eroding. The question isn’t if the dollar will lose supremacy – it’s when Kenneth Mohammed Diverse, communal, gender-fluid: African families’ true history is being whitewashed Wambui Esther Kimani Women in India don’t want ‘safe zones’ – they want to enjoy public spaces as equals Nilanjana Bhowmick How did Spain come to be one of the few nations holding firm on aid spending? Ana Carbajosa In pictures Hide Women behind the lens: bending over backwards for luck Colombian artist and photographer Isabella Madrid explores the ‘click to be saved’ economy of hope in her project, Lucky Girl Syndrome Southern frontlines Hide ‘We want Starlink’: from isolation to integration – what happened to the Korubo people after contact? Missionaries using secret audio devices to evangelise Brazil’s isolated peoples ‘A computer, a radio, a drone and a shotgun’: how missionaries are reaching out to Brazil’s isolated peoples It is a potentially lethal chemical – but even Mexico’s cartels can’t resist the lure of mercury Explainers Hide Sudan’s civil war: how did it begin, what is the human cost, and what is happening now? Are we ready for another pandemic? What is gender apartheid – and can anything be done to stop it? How much does the UK spend on overseas aid – and where does the money go? Multimedia Hide Ulaanbaatar: a warning from the coldest capital on Earth - podcast Podcast 24:48 A street in Gaza, a map of dreams, and the people desperate to live How Europe closed its borders and betrayed its values – video Video Get involved Hide Her Stage newsletter Hear directly from incredible women from around the world on the issues that matter most to them Newsletter Global Dispatch newsletter Sign up for a different world view N
headings: Global development

title: Video + Comment | The Guardian
body:
Video + Comment January 2025 Anywhere but Westminster Do Trump's politics connect in these English towns? - video As the second Trump presidency begins, John Harris and John Domokos go to a Staffordshire town whose economy went from coal to Amazon warehousing to find out if 21st century populism is cutting through Video 14:58 June 2024 Anywhere but Westminster Here's what you find under Labour's 'landslide': doubters, abstainers and independents - video Video 16:24 Anywhere but Westminster Why are the Tories collapsing? These true-blue towns know the answers - video Video 15:51 May 2021 Anywhere but Westminster Hands, face and empty space: where Covid has left politics - video Among vacant shops and 15% unemployment, John Harris and John Domokos get immersed in Birmingham as it emerges from the pandemic. Amid despair, they discover hope - focused not on a Tory/Labour race for mayor, but communities brilliantly helping themselves Video 17:02 September 2020 Owen Jones meets... From Mary Whitehouse to the proms: Owen Jones on how ‘woke’ became a dirty word - video By 2020 everything from the proms to sausage rolls were said to be at risk from 'woke' online warriors. But what does it even mean to be woke? Who were the original anti-woke campaigners? And who benefits and suffers when these manufactured culture wars divide us? Owen Jones – often described as 'too woke' himself – tries to find out Video 14:31 June 2020 Anywhere but Westminster Life in lockdown: Covid-19, BLM and inequality in east London – video As people emerge into a changed reality, the Anywhere But Westminster team focus on East London, where Covid-19 has fused with the Black Lives Matter movement and huge injustices are impossible to ignore Live May 2020 A new normal Who do you trust on coronavirus? From Trudeau to Piers Morgan | A new normal Video 7:51 Anywhere but Westminster Life in lockdown: how to keep a city alive  – video Live April 2020 A new normal What do you want the post-coronavirus future to look like? – video Live Anywhere but Westminster Life in lockdown: families on the brink – video Video 15:41 Anywhere but Westminster Life in lockdown: how our jobs turned upside down – video Video 14:01 Jan Fran's the frant The Frant: You need to stay home, and not just because it's the law now – video Video 4:10 March 2020 ‘How do we survive coronavirus?’ Owen Jones meets low-paid workers – video Owen Jones spoke to some of the low-paid and precarious workers expected to be hit hardest by the Covid-19 crisis in the weeks ahead Video 11:00 December 2019 Anywhere but Westminster Anywhere but Westminster: how Labour lost, and the hope that endures – video John Harris and John Domokos finish their road trip and among the electoral rubble, they find overlooked signs of a better future Video 18:00 Anywhere but Westminster Anywhere but Westminster | Scotland: fear and Lothian on the campaign trail – video As election day nears, John Harris and John Domokos head for a SNP/Labour marginal Video 14:29 Anywhere but Westminster Anywhere but Westminster: will Labour's 'red wall' hold in this election? – video John Harris and John Domokos continue their election road trip, travelling through crucial seats that have traditionally been loyal to Labour but where a majority voted leave and the Tories are now encroaching. What they find defies the usual political cliches Video 20:09 November 2019 Anywhere but Westminster Anywhere but Westminster: homeless people, the voters without a voice – video Video 14:18 Owen Jones: ‘They don’t want you to vote. Defy them’ Video 2:05 Anywhere but Westminster Anywhere But Westminster: are the Tories losing their suburban heartlands? – video Video 14:55 Anywhere but Westminster Beyond Brexit, Corbyn and Johnson: Stoke's politics of hope – video Video 13:41 About 507 results for Video + Comment 1 2 3 4 ...

title: Music | The Guardian
body: Music Art ‘Flyovers can be incredibly beautiful!’ Long Blondes singer Kate Jackson’s new career as a motorway artist In her neck scarf and beret, she sang songs that defined the 2000s. title: Art and design, photography and architecture | The Guardian
